{"code":1,"isDone":false,"toInsertArticleList":[{"createdTime":"2021-10-01 10:08:05","updatedTime":"2021-10-01 10:08:05","title":"I spent 13 years studying the fine art of haggling: here is what I learned","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/heres-what-i-learned-studying-the-fine-art-of-haggling-2021-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6155f2cc7b09e80018e59435?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Several people hold up and inspect a rug\" height=\"3464\" width=\"5196\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A rug salesman shows off a rug at The Grand Bazaar in Istanbul, Turkey.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Tim Graham/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Why do people from different cultures haggle and what are the best tricks? </li>\n<li><a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCXsQlHGuoWqukC9vz-uonrg\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"20\" data-uri=\"744129ce643a030c7595de821f3f07fc\">Collin Abroadcast</a>, who posts his shopping exploits on YouTube, calls it &#34;really rapid negotiation. Where you think on your feet.&#34;</li>\n<li>&#34;I wanna talk with them...I wanna have a certain vibe,&#34; travel blogger <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCUJB5jUIJcucWe5dTpjvuvQ\">Sassy Funke</a> says of bargain shopping in her native Nigeria.</li>\n<li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider&#39;s business page</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Funke Ogunkoya-Futi - aka<a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCUJB5jUIJcucWe5dTpjvuvQ\"> Sassy Funke</a>, travel blogger, vlogger, and the author of the <em>Lagos Travel Guide -</em> was ambling through the alleys of Nigeria&#39;s Lekki Arts and Crafts Market early one morning last July, just before the rush of shoppers. Her goal: attain ready-made African clothing for her Canadian in-laws.</p><p>She browsed the closet-sized shops spilling out with jewelry and gems, furniture and tribal masks, woven baskets and wax print bags. Paintings stacked on paintings stacked on paintings. As she peeked into stores, shopkeepers called out, &#34;Come, mama. I have it. I have what you&#39;re looking for.&#34;</p><p>She was comparing prices at multiple shops when she spotted a dress she loved. The shopkeeper asked for 2000 naira (about $4.87). Normally, no matter the price asked, Ogunkoya-Futi shoots shopkeepers a look of utter shock and then offers to pay something &#34;ridiculous,&#34; she told me. If something is 100 naira, she offers 5.</p><p>But the dress was good quality; 2000 naira was already a great price. She offered 1000 naira.</p><p>Ogunkoya-Futi performed masterful schmoozing, talking the seller up and calling herself his daughter. She offered to make multiple purchases and refer him to her friends. Twenty minutes of back and forth later, she secured the deal.</p><p>Then, Ogunkoya-Futi asked him to throw in three headbands.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6155f6177b09e80018e59559?format=jpeg\" alt=\"A women displays a West African fabric with piles of other options behind her.\" height=\"2832\" width=\"4256\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Adenike Akinlosose, an African textiles dealer, shows her fabrics at Balogun market in Lagos in 2011.\n<p class=\"copyright\">PIUS UTOMI EKPEI/AFP via Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>&#34;This&#39;ll cost you nothing to make,&#34; Ogunkoya-Futi said, holding the headbands aloft.</p><p>He gave them to her for free.</p><p>Ogunkoya-Futi beams when sharing the story with me during an interview over Zoom, claiming it was her best haggling experience because she and the shopkeeper sparked a connection, both had a pleasant experience, and she brought three friends back that week to support his shop. Ogunkoya-Futi had scored a great deal - and helped a kind businessman. </p><p>&#34;I love the interaction,&#34; she told me. &#34;I wanna talk with them. I wanna gist with them. I wanna have a certain vibe, and they enjoy that, they get that.&#34;</p><p>There&#39;s also the rush of adrenaline. <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCXsQlHGuoWqukC9vz-uonrg\">Collin Abroadcast</a>, a YouTuber who gets millions of views when he posts his shopping exploits, defines haggling as &#34;really rapid negotiation. Where you think on your feet. It&#39;s a game, and the more you play, the more you gain speed and learn to read people&#39;s body language.&#34;</p><h2><strong>A good deal between friends</strong></h2><p>I also love a good haggle. I haggled for my wife&#39;s engagement ring, and before our wedding, I haggled for catering, a DJ, and a photographer. Soon after, I haggled for our house, and when we started our family, I haggled for a minivan. </p><p>I honed my skills during my time living in Jerusalem for nine months in the mid-aughts when I was 27. I was interning at a Jewish-Arab equality NGO and making little money.</p><p>In Israel, haggling is hardcore. Sellers go from telling you that you look like a celebrity to cursing you out. I perfected the interest-indifference ratio, always walking out of a store with a salesperson trailing me, hollering deals. I would get into cabs, then immediately back out, if they didn&#39;t knock the price down. </p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6155f92ab414c100186323df?format=jpeg\" alt=\"A man sits in a stall selling a variety of jewelry\" height=\"3648\" width=\"5472\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Italian craftsman Antonio Ignomeriello in his shop at Las Dalias night market in San Carlos, on Ibiza Island in 2021.\n<p class=\"copyright\">JAIME REINA/AFP via Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>My grandfather was a haggler. He escaped the antisemitism and pogroms of Poland for America in 1917 and desperately drove his roots into upstate New York&#39;s soil, peddling scrap metal, haggling over prices, and eventually saving enough to start a tailored suit shop/dry cleaners, which soon became a suit shop/paint store, and finally Deitcher&#39;s Wallpaper and Design Center in Cohoes, New York, established in 1926.</p><p>Born in 1937, my father was heir to the business. Over lunches at Smith&#39;s Tavern, he haggled deals with distributors, loading up on stock in exchange for a bigger discount. In return, customers asked for discounts, too, and if they purchased enough, of course he hooked them up.</p><p>When my father grew up it was easier for independent businesses to thrive. Store owners were from the community. Customers trusted them because they were neighbors and family. Clerks could make deals, usually cutting into their commission. Shop owners haggled with other shop owners who then haggled deals back. Supporting each other was supporting friends. </p><p>Today, the only things you can haggle for in the United States are cars, houses, fine jewelry, large appliances, home repairs, event services, and graphic novels at Comic Con. There&#39;s little hope for small businesses cutting deals with distributors when Walmart goes directly to manufacturers to demand the lowest wholesale rates.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6155fef8b414c10018632666?format=jpeg\" alt=\"A pile of tugs outside a market stall.\" height=\"2678\" width=\"4012\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Rugs for sale at the Jaffa Flea Market in Tel Aviv in 2018.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Michael Jacobs/Art in All of Us/Corbis via Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>In the 80s, Deitcher&#39;s Wallpaper grew to the point that my father couldn&#39;t order wallpaper fast enough, so he bought a warehouse. In the 90s, he moved the family into his custom-built dream house: 5,600 square feet in Slingerlands, New York-the country-where we were one of a handful of Jewish families in the school district and barely knew our neighbors. Then the business faltered. For years, my father tried running new promotions, but the store bled money and most of his income was from investments. In the early aughts, he held a final sale, donated his stock to Habitat for Humanity, and became an appointment-only interior decorator.</p><p>Even my father shops on Amazon now.</p><h2><strong>&#34;Never, never, take it personally. Never get angry.&#34;</strong></h2><p>But while America becomes less able to negotiate, people fiend to watch the art of haggling. Abroadcast, the haggling YouTuber, has 1.42 million followers on the platform. His comments sections are filled with fans peeping into a world they will never experience.</p><p>Born in Waukesha, Wisconsin, Abroadcast started his channel making &#34;typical travel Vlog type stuff,&#34; he told me via Zoom. &#34;Here I am as a foreigner living in China.&#34; He had never haggled in his life before he visited the fake markets in Shanghai five years ago. He envisioned back-alley hustlers, but found a five-story mall in the middle of the city. He caught on immediately, bargaining over a pair of Nikes he knew were bootleg. He felt the rush of adrenaline. The connection with sellers.</p><iframe width=\"560\" height=\"315\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/Aoq9hat-kZs\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen=\"\"></iframe><p> </p><p>His schtick became hopping from country to country-India, Morocco, Kenya, 20 countries overall-rocking two days of stubble, a t-shirt or a hoodie, and a backpack. His videos run 20 minutes to over an hour, with scene after scene of him haggling and chatting with sellers. Sometimes the haggles get tense, frustration sparking between both the seller and Abroadcast. To some viewers, I&#39;m sure he can come off as a white American trying to acquire goods for peanuts, but often you see him taking his time to learn about a seller&#39;s art and family. He can be genuine, both calling out fake goods and complimenting what he likes.</p><p>&#34;I know straight off the bat, especially me being a foreigner in these markets, they expect me to have money because I&#39;m on vacation,&#34; he said. &#34;So obviously, they&#39;re going to take their chance and try to overcharge me.&#34;</p><p>His favorite story, he told me, <a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rgvfKvl7zWA\">took place in Beijing&#39;s Silk Market</a>, a massive modern mall known as a destination for buying knock-offs.</p><iframe width=\"560\" height=\"315\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/rgvfKvl7zWA\" frameborder=\"0\" allowfullscreen=\"\"></iframe><p> </p><p>In a shop lined with shoes, a seller rejected his offer of 200 yuan (about $32) for a pair of Jordans. He told her, &#34;I&#39;m good, I&#39;m good,&#34; and headed for the exit. The seller reeled him back in, reminding him he was being unreasonable because she was selling him Jordans, &#34;not lady shoes, not baby shoes, not socks.&#34; She fed him tons of snark, which he met with laughter. She finally lowered her price to 250 because he was &#34;very handsome,&#34; but he left empty handed, holding firm at his offer of 200.</p><p>&#34;My best haggling situation isn&#39;t where I get the best price, it&#39;s where I have the most fun. And the seller has the most fun as well,&#34; he said. &#34;Those are always the best times because it&#39;s like, &#39;Alright, let&#39;s put my skills to the test.&#39; The worst ones are when the sellers don&#39;t really care to sell to you.&#34;</p><p>&#34;Never, never, take it personally. Never get angry,&#34; Abroadcast said. &#34;As humans, we all want the same thing. Everybody just wants to have good health. They want to be loved and be able to support their family at the end of the day.&#34;</p><h2><strong>&#34;Just pay the dollar and go&#34;</strong></h2><p>My mom-in-law, who grew up in Jamaica in the &#39;60s, didn&#39;t feel a connection with the buyers she haggled with. She did it because that&#39;s how her family got by.</p><p>Once a week, she, her mom, and her sisters went shopping in the bend-down markets of Saint Elizabeth, a parish in the south of Jamaica, known for having the reddest dirt and the Appleton rum estate. Sellers spread their goods on blankets, and often, my mom-in-law and her family came with their own crop to sell-thyme, scallions, and coffee beans from their farm-while their mom used profits to haggle for soup meat, liver, and kidney.</p><p>Many of my mom-in-law&#39;s family members loved chatting with buyers, but she hated it. &#34;It kind of made me feel a little…&#34; her voice trailed off while she told me about it from across the kitchen table. She remembered feeling ashamed as she watched school friends wandering by, purchasing things, while she fought over small sums of money. &#34;You know how children are. They would say, &#39;hey, I saw her in the market selling.&#39; It was down-grading.&#34;</p><p>Once her secondary school finished, she left the farm and eventually made her way to America, where she attained her dream job at New York City&#39;s Waldorf Astoria, a stark contrast to the markets. To this day, she is one of the worst hagglers I&#39;ve seen. &#34;She gets embarrassed. Has too much pride,&#34; my wife told me. &#34;She worries haggling makes her seem less-than.&#34;</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6155fdaeb414c100186325d6?format=jpeg\" alt=\"A woman stands near a stall selling handmade baskets.\" height=\"2440\" width=\"3719\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A basket seller in Jamaica.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Emmanuel VALENTIN/Gamma-Rapho via Getty Images)</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>&#34;I can&#39;t do it,&#34; my mom-in-law said, stirring her tea. &#34;If they say this thing is for a dollar, I just pay the dollar and go. It&#39;s up to them and their conscience. I don&#39;t lose.&#34;</p><p>She loves chatting with the sales people, whether it be in Macy&#39;s or a market in Ocho Rios. She will even leave sellers tips. &#34;I remember my days when I didn&#39;t have it,&#34; she said. &#34;I know how it&#39;s hard.&#34;</p><h2><strong>&#34;You don&#39;t leave money on the table.&#34;</strong></h2><p>Last February, my wife and I took my mom-in-law and my son to visit Jerusalem, and we strolled through the shuk, my mom-in-law paying what she pleased while I went to work.</p><p>I was in my element.</p><p>Roni Peled, senior tour guide and Director of Guide Activities at the Israel Museum, told me that since the Crusades, the streets of Jerusalem&#39;s Old City have been named for different goods and services. &#34;If I open a shop of spices, right away, on my right side and my left side, there would be open another shop of spices,&#34; he said. The Ottoman Empire divided the wide, slippery limestone streets into alleys, a half or quarter their original size, creating the maze of vibrant markets of today. Growing up refugees in the 50s, Peled&#39;s family couldn&#39;t afford plays and movies, so going to the markets was how they entertained themselves. Everyone met in the markets.</p><p>Arabs shopped from Jewish shops and Jews frequented Arab shops, but Peled worries the bonds created in Jerusalem&#39;s markets are becoming a thing of the past. In 2008, right before I left Jerusalem, the Mamilla Mall opened, just outside the Old City, leading to Jaffa Gate. It&#39;s a massive open-air shopping center featuring haggle-free high-end international chain stores built around and into historical buildings. I enjoy shopping there the same way I love my local mall, but the experience feels very impersonal.</p><p>Haggling is changing in Nigeria, too, at least for more financially comfortable Nigerians in cities like Lagos.</p><p>Back when Ogunkoya-Futi was growing up in the 90s, going to a proper grocery store was a trip, but it&#39;s becoming more the norm. &#34;They&#39;re becoming formal entities,&#34; she told me, &#34;with a PNL, with projections.&#34; Nigerians can get most anything delivered through Jumia, known as the Amazon of Africa. There are hundreds of dispatch services-delivering food, clothing, and TVs.</p><p>She sees merchants struggling and understands why many Nigerian businesses are becoming more formal. &#34;I can take a random vendor in the market that people haggle with on a day-to-day basis. He sells his products one day for 15. The next day, 100. The fundamental issue is that he can&#39;t plan. The fundamental issue is that he has constant bills that are fixed or even growing that he might not be able to live up to.&#34; Yet because other vendors are haggling, he can&#39;t afford to stop.</p><p>&#34;I love the haggling culture,&#34; Ogunkoya-Futi said. &#34;But I think it&#39;s unpredictability of revenue is a big issue in the market.&#34; It&#39;s one of the reasons, she told me, many Nigerians are dependent on diaspora money to survive.</p><p>Stelios Michalopoulos, an economics professor at Brown University, tells me that societies where haggling is a big part of commercial interactions often share a way of valuing time. &#34;If time is expensive, then you would not do it,&#34; he said. &#34;When labor cost is low, then your time is cheap.&#34;</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6155fc4d7b09e80018e597ba?format=jpeg\" alt=\"A customer hands over money to sellers at a flea market.\" height=\"2396\" width=\"3500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A stall selling antiques, at El Rastro, Madrid&#39;s iconic flea market, in 2021.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Gustavo Valiente/Europa Press via Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>It&#39;s also more common where a higher value is placed on social interactions, there is a joy in haggling. &#34;Both the buyer and the seller want the other to be happy,&#34; so they can &#34;invite for further interactions,&#34; Michalopoulos said. Of course, that makes less sense when it comes to tourists, who are unlikely to return consistently.</p><p>He told me that he believes haggling and formalized trade systems can work together. He used donation-based alumni organizations as a parallel example. Donors set the value of being involved with organizations-giving $50 or $100 or whatever they want based on their interest-and the organizations run fine.</p><p>He called haggling &#34;the optimal way to sell&#34; because the buyer pays &#34;according to his marginal willingness to pay, which will be higher than the cost to the supplier.&#34; The possibility for price differentiation leaves no unexploited opportunities for trade.</p><p>&#34;If you have one single price economy,&#34; he said, and something costs the seller $8 and the market price goes for $10, &#34;there are actually trades that could have taken place at eight-and-a-half bucks, nine bucks, nine-and-a-half bucks.&#34;</p><p>&#34;The single price law kills those possibilities,&#34; he said.</p><p>If a buyer is willing to pay anything above the seller&#39;s cost, &#34;You don&#39;t lose. You don&#39;t leave money on the table.&#34;</p><p>Today, Ogunkoya-Futi travels the world, documenting her journey to over 35 countries, but she often finds herself haggling with favorite food sellers back home over 10 naira (about $.024).</p><p>And she says bringing the haggling mentality into other aspects of your life &#34;can open doors that you don&#39;t even know.&#34; It&#39;s about ingenuity. &#34;Don&#39;t be discouraged by the hard print,&#34; she said. If a job says you need to apply by the first of the month but it&#39;s the second, &#34;find the right person in that company. They&#39;ll put your application through.&#34; If a job can&#39;t meet your salary demands, ask if they can bundle it with other benefits, stock options, or travel credits. &#34;Don&#39;t be so fixed on one point, look for other creative ways to make a deal better for you.&#34;</p><p>&#34;If you&#39;re personable,&#34; Ogunkoya-Futi said, &#34;you just never know.&#34;</p><div Deitcher)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/6155f2cc7b09e80018e59435?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn88@2020_5/2021/10/01/02-08-35-871_1ba8a8730bbd5fd6.webp","https://i.insider.com/6155f6177b09e80018e59559?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn52@2020_5/2021/10/01/02-08-34-411_3d584a33ed3e39db.webp","https://i.insider.com/6155f92ab414c100186323df?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn63@2020_4/2021/10/01/02-08-35-898_8729482cf3f00540.webp","https://i.insider.com/6155fef8b414c10018632666?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn15@2020_2/2021/10/01/02-08-36-334_a3e134265ef58eb4.webp","https://i.insider.com/6155fdaeb414c100186325d6?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn36@2020_4/2021/10/01/02-08-36-242_8ba082653fdad75b.webp","https://i.insider.com/6155fc4d7b09e80018e597ba?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn88@2020_3/2021/10/01/02-08-31-236_e501901e8f4888e1.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn83@2020_1/2021/10/01/02-08-34-915_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=Zh9QqD5z2PE:VspbrG3Q8lk:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn8@2020_5/2021/10/01/02-08-36-033_4162f7c15e8b993d.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=Zh9QqD5z2PE:VspbrG3Q8lk:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn28@2020_2/2021/10/01/02-08-32-839_7fb3788873fba514.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn99@2020_6/2021/10/01/02-08-33-043_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=Zh9QqD5z2PE:VspbrG3Q8lk:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn71@2020_4/2021/10/01/02-08-31-147_76af3df28ead92f9.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/Zh9QqD5z2PE":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn28@2020_2/2021/10/01/02-08-34-030_854035dd6ad00f9d.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1633054085766},{"createdTime":"2021-10-01 10:08:05","updatedTime":"2021-10-01 10:08:05","title":"Joe Manchin, who is holding up crucial climate change initiatives in Biden's reconciliation bill, collects $500,000 a year from coal stocks dividends: report","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/senator-joe-manchin-half-million-year-coal-stocks-climate-crisis-2021-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6155f698b414c100186322c1?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Democratic Sen. Joe Manchin of West Virginia during the Senate Appropriations Committee markup of the FY 22 Energy and Water, Agriculture, and MilCon VA Appropriations Bills on August 04, 2021.\" height=\"2672\" width=\"3563\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Democratic Sen. Joe Manchin of West Virginia during the Senate Appropriations Committee markup of the FY 22 Energy and Water, Agriculture, and MilCon VA Appropriations Bills on August 04, 2021.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Tom Williams/CQ-Roll Call/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Sen. Joe Manchin earned $500,000 in 2020 from his son&#39;s energy firm, which Manchin founded in 1998.</li>\n<li>He&#39;s also the chair of the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee, which regulates the industry.</li>\n<li>He&#39;s received thousands from Exxon lobbyists and Republican oil and gas titans.</li>\n<li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider&#39;s business page</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Democratic Sen. Joe Manchin of West Virginia, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/joe-manchin-never-been-liberal-2-trillion-cuts-reconciliation-bill-2021-9\">who has in his own words &#34;never been in a liberal in any way shape or form,&#34;</a> is currently holding up the $3.5 trillion reconciliation bill that central to President Joe Biden&#39;s &#34;Build Back Better&#34; domestic agenda.</p><p>But he&#39;s also likely to hold back any further action to combat the climate crisis, which could impact his million-dollar investments in the coal and energy industries.</p><p><a href=\"https://www.cnn.com/2021/07/14/politics/joe-manchin-reconciliation-climate-change/index.html\">Manchin told CNN in July</a> that he was disturbed by aspects of the $3.5 trillion reconciliation bill, including provisions that would target the fossil fuel industry.</p><p>&#34;I&#39;m finding out there&#39;s a lot of language in places they&#39;re eliminating fossils, which is very, very disturbing, because if you&#39;re sticking your head in the sand, and saying that fossil (fuel) has to be eliminated in America, and they want to get rid of it, and thinking that&#39;s going to clean up the global climate, it won&#39;t clean it up all,&#34; Manchin said. &#34;If anything, it would be worse.&#34;</p><p>As <a href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2021/jul/20/joe-manchin-big-oil-democratic-senator\">The Guardian reported</a> in partnership with <a href=\"https://www.exposedbycmd.org/\" data-link-name=\"in body link\">the Center for Media and Democracy</a> in July, Manchin himself founded a private coal brokerage in 1998 called &#34;Enersystems.&#34; Though currently run by his son, Manchin still owns as much as a $5 million stake in the company, raking in $500,000 of income from it in 2020 alone. As of late 2019, Manchin was by far the most invested of any senator in &#34;dirty energy.&#34;</p><p>Manchin serves as chair of the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee, which oversees the coal industry as well as &#34;global climate change.&#34; As <a href=\"https://readsludge.com/2021/07/01/manchin-profits-from-coal-sales-to-utility-lobbying-group-members/\">Sludge reported in early July</a>, Manchin told the 2021 annual conference of the Edison Electric Institute in June that &#34;coal-fired plants are being unfairly targeted by environmentalists.&#34;</p><p>Manchin also draws significant campaign funding from the energy industry as well, including $65,000 from oil giant Exxon&#39;s lobbyists and political action committee. He also <a href=\"https://www.texastribune.org/2021/07/15/joe-manchin-texas-fundraiser-republicans/\">attended a July fundraiser in Houston</a> held by a number of Texas oil and gas titans who otherwise donate exclusively to Republicans.</p><p>Keith McCoy, Exxon&#39;s senior director of federal relations, bragged in a leaked video recording that he talked to Manchin&#39;s office every week. &#34;He is the kingmaker, and he&#39;s not shy about staking his claim early and completely changing the debate,&#34; he said.</p><p>In contrast, Manchin does not seem to engage as much with activists concerned about the climate crisis.</p><p>&#34;We do not speak to Manchin&#39;s office every week. This is bullshit,&#34; the Sunrise Movement&#39;s communications director, Ellen Sciales, <a href=\"https://www.huffpost.com/entry/joe-manchin-exxonmobil-lobbying-environmental-groups_n_60dcc8e3e4b001b8d59bbbd8\">told the Huffington Post</a>. &#34;Especially as there are unprecedented and fatal heat waves across the country, it&#39;s outrageous that our politicians are working with the very people responsible for the extreme weather instead of looking out for the American people.&#34;</p><p> </p><p> </p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/senator-joe-manchin-half-million-year-coal-stocks-climate-crisis-2021-9'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a Metzger)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/6155f698b414c100186322c1?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn16@2020_1/2021/10/01/02-08-27-281_1acb7480d41c71cf.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn83@2020_1/2021/10/01/02-08-34-915_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=aMTbBQ98Hr8:8ovvgLcl52c:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn56@2020_5/2021/10/01/02-08-34-357_61d88908930c6163.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=aMTbBQ98Hr8:8ovvgLcl52c:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn40@2020_5/2021/10/01/02-08-33-287_e1757bd4f2bb0f89.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn99@2020_6/2021/10/01/02-08-33-043_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=aMTbBQ98Hr8:8ovvgLcl52c:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn63@2020_2/2021/10/01/02-08-50-472_2b4eac73979ba4b6.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/aMTbBQ98Hr8":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn64@2020_3/2021/10/01/02-08-32-322_0dcea0e6fabf2326.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1633054085738},{"createdTime":"2021-10-01 10:08:05","updatedTime":"2021-10-01 10:08:05","title":"The best cast iron skillets and pans we tested in 2021","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/best-cast-iron-skillet","description":"<bi-shortcode id=\"table-of-contents-sticky\" class=\"mceNonEditable\" data-type=\"h2\">Table of Contents: Masthead Sticky</bi-shortcode><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Cast iron skillets offer the best heat retention of any cookware material; plus, they can last for decades.</li>\n<li id=\"recirc\">Our pick for the best overall cast iron skillet is the <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/reviews/out?u=https%3A%2F%2Ffieldcompany.com%2Fproducts%2Ffield-cast-iron-skillet\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored\">Field 10.25&#34; Cast Iron Skillet</a>.</li>\n<li>The skillet seared steak without overcooking it, baked a well-risen cornbread, and quickly became nonstick.</li>\n</ul><p>In my reporting for Insider, I speak to many chefs and I often ask them what their favorite kitchen tool is and why. The vast majority of them give me two answers: their chef&#39;s knife and cast iron skillet. Executive chef at the <a href=\"https://www.escoffier.edu/about/chef-instructors/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Auguste Escoffier School of Culinary Arts</a> in Austin, Texas, Chef Robyn McArthur said of her cast iron skillet, &#34;I keep mine on my stove at all times and use it every day. It is versatile, easy to maintain, and cooks everything beautifully.&#34; </p><p>One of the best features of cast iron skillets, especially those we recommend below, is how you can cook anything in any way on them. Cast iron actually improves with age as seasoning builds up on the surface, said Atara Bernstein, co-founder of <a href=\"https://pineapplecollaborative.com/about\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Pineapple Collaborative</a>. These pans often become legacy pieces, passed down from one generation of cooks to the next. However, cast iron can be an investment -- if not in price, then in the maintenance of the seasoning and difficulty maneuvering the heavy pan. It&#39;s important to get the best one for you and your style of cooking.</p><p>In support of my testing, I spoke with Chef Robyn McArthur, Atara Berstein, and Ariel Pasternak, the other co-founder of <a href=\"https://pineapplecollaborative.com/about\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">Pineapple Collaborative</a>, about their experiences with cast iron and why it is a chef favorite. I then cooked six steaks, six cornbreads, and six sunny side-up eggs to determine the best cast iron skillets of 2021.</p><h2>Here are the best cast iron skillets of 2021</h2><ul class=\"summary-list\"><li><strong>Best cast iron skillet overall: </strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/reviews/out?u=https%3A%2F%2Ffieldcompany.com%2Fproducts%2Ffield-cast-iron-skillet\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored\"><strong>Field 10.25&#34; Cast Iron Skillet</strong></a></li><li><strong>Best budget cast iron skillet: </strong><a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/Lodge-Skillet-Pre-Seasoned-Ready-Stove/dp/B00006JSUA\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow nofollow noopener sponsored sponsored\"><strong>Lodge 10.25&#34; Classic Cast Iron Skillet</strong></a></li><li><strong>Best cast iron skillet for searing: </strong><a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/Creuset-Signature-Handle-Skillet-4-Inch/dp/B009ZML3UK\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow nofollow noopener sponsored sponsored\"><strong>Le Creuset 10&#34; Signature Skillet</strong></a></li></ul>\n<div id=\"slideshow\">\n\tThe best cast iron skillet overall\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6154894cb414c1001862ea7e?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Cornbread baked in the best overall cast iron skillet, the Field 10.25” Cast Iron Skillet.\" height=\"808\" width=\"1078\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Lily Alig/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><strong>The <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/reviews/out?u=https%3A%2F%2Ffieldcompany.com%2Fproducts%2Ffield-cast-iron-skillet\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored\">Field 10.25\" Cast Iron Skillet</a> is the ideal cast iron skillet to have in your kitchen; it sears as well as it bakes, and develops a smooth, nonstick surface after just a few uses.</strong></p><p><strong>Pros: </strong>Even heat retention, great sear on the steak, quick to develop seasoning</p><p><strong>Cons: </strong>Helper handle is not very helpful, no pour spouts</p><p>Any new piece of cookware takes some getting used to -- how fast and evenly it heats, or how much fat it needs to prevent sticking. Cast iron can be particularly intimidating, but I felt comfortable right away using the Field pan. It is lighter than most of the other pans we tested and cleaned easily.</p><p>Like many of the skillets, the <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/reviews/out?u=https%3A%2F%2Ffieldcompany.com%2Fproducts%2Ffield-cast-iron-skillet\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored\">Field</a> arrived pre-seasoned. In our first test, the cornbread did not turn out when flipped, but it was easy to remove individual pieces without any crust sticking to the bottom. The seasoning, and therefore nonstick quality, became even better throughout our testing. After searing the steak and cleaning the skillet, I could feel the surface become smoother. When I later cooked the egg, it slid right off the surface without a trace stuck to the pan.&#160;</p><p>The steak cooked evenly and seared quickly in the <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/reviews/out?u=https%3A%2F%2Ffieldcompany.com%2Fproducts%2Ffield-cast-iron-skillet\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored\">Field</a> pan, allowing a great crust to develop without overcooking. Additionally, the cornbread had an even brown exterior and smooth, risen top.</p>\n\tBest budget cast iron skillet\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/61548bb92fb46b0019be98db?format=jpeg\" alt=\"The best budget cast iron skillet, the Lodge 10.25” Cast Iron Skillet, with seared steak.\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Lily Alig/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><strong>The affordable <a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/Lodge-Skillet-Pre-Seasoned-Ready-Stove/dp/B00006JSUA\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored\">Lodge 10.25\" Cast Iron Skillet</a> excels in everything you expect cast iron to do, from retaining heat to providing a naturally nonstick surface.</strong></p><p><strong>Pros: </strong>Fully nonstick after a few uses, useful pour spouts, even heating</p><p><strong>Cons: </strong>Slower to heat up&#160;</p><p>Nothing stuck to the <a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/Lodge-Skillet-Pre-Seasoned-Ready-Stove/dp/B00006JSUA\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored\">Lodge 10.25\" Cast Iron Skillet</a>. The cornbread turned out perfectly, without a crumb left on the bottom, and the eggs slid off the surface without breaking. In part because it turned out unblemished, the bottom of the Lodge cornbread was the most even golden-brown of those we made.</p><p>The shallow pour spouts were very helpful when pouring out grease and oil from cooking the steak. The handle is shorter than that of our top pick, but both got hot to the touch quickly.&#160;</p><p>It was a close call for the best overall skillet between this pan and Field. Lodge fell out of the top spot because of the searing test: a crust did develop on the Lodge steak, but it took longer to achieve a darker brown. This could lead to overcooking in an effort to get a better crust. The Le Creuset and Field skillets produced thicker crusts in a shorter amount of time.</p>\n\tBest cast iron skillet for searing\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/61548c332fb46b0019be9912?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Our best cast iron skillet for searing, the Le Creuset 10” Signature Skillet.\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Lily Alig/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><strong>The <a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/Creuset-Signature-Handle-Skillet-4-Inch/dp/B009ZML3UK\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored nofollow sponsored\">Le Creuset 10\" Signature Skillet</a> is a must-have for meat-eaters, searing steak to perfection quicker than any other pans we tested.</strong></p><p><strong>Pros: </strong>Heats up quickly and stays hot for as long as you're cooking, even heat distribution&#160;</p><p><strong>Cons: </strong>Not good for baking, heavy</p><p>If you can't cook outdoors, searing on a good cast iron pan can be a substitute for grilling, said Pasternak. While you can't mimic the smokiness of open flame cooking, the heavy bottom and heat retention of cast iron pans can sear and char your food. The <a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/Creuset-Signature-Handle-Skillet-4-Inch/dp/B009ZML3UK\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored nofollow sponsored\">Le Creuset Signature Skillet</a> produced the best sear of all the pans we tested.</p><p>Many of the steaks I made ended up with crispy and deep brown crusts, but the steak cooked in the Le Creuset had a beautiful sear within the first few minutes of cooking. For me, this made it easier to achieve the medium-rare cook that I prefer; I didn't have to keep the steak on the pan past when it was done to my liking in an effort to achieve the sear.<strong>&#160;</strong></p><p>This was notably heavier than the other skillets, almost impossible for me to lift and keep level with one hand. Additionally, the Le Creuset did produce a low risen cornbread that stuck to the bottom of the pan.&#160;</p>\n\tWhat else we tested\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/61549006b414c1001862ed1d?format=jpeg\" alt=\"All six cast iron skillets that we tested stacked on top of each other.\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Lily Alig/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><strong><a href=\"https://www.amazon.com/dp/B01726HDY0\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored\">Victoria 10\" Cast Iron Skillet:</a></strong> By a fair margin, the Victoria pan produced the tallest cornbread. It is not one of our top picks because while it did well, it did not outperform the others in the steak or egg test. It is a solid choice for a low-cost cast iron skillet.</p><p><strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/reviews/out?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.williams-sonoma.com%2Fproducts%2Fstaub-fry-pan\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored\">Staub Enameled Cast Iron Fry Pan:</a> </strong>This is one of the most beautiful pans I have tested, but the overall performance was just average. The cornbread did not rise as much in this pan as in others, and the eggs were difficult to remove, leaving some pieces stuck to the surface.</p><p><strong>Zest Cast Iron Pan [Currently out of stock]:</strong> Another beautiful piece of cookware, the Zest pan seared the steak well and cooked a well-risen cornbread. However, a thin layer of the cornbread stuck to the bottom of the pan, and the eggs were difficult to remove as well. The stickiness of the nonstick interior kept this pan out of a top spot.</p>\n\tOur testing methodology\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/61548e062fb46b0019be9979?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Measuring the height of cornbread cooked in our best overall cast iron skillet, the Field 10.25” Cast Iron Skillet.\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Lily Alig/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p>For consistency, we only tested 10 to 10.5-inch skillets. We conducted three cooking tests to evaluate the different aspects of performance.</p><p>All cast iron pans are heavier than aluminum or even stainless steel. We compared the weight of these skillets to each other and found minimal differences. All of the skillets had one extended handle and one helper handle. However, we preferred pans with helper handles that you could fit your fingers in, as opposed to just extended grips.&#160;</p><p><strong>Cornbread:</strong> We used <a href=\"https://cooking.nytimes.com/recipes/9375-cornbread\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored\">Mark Bittman's NYTCooking Cornbread Recip</a>e to evaluate the heat retention and distribution of each pan. We measured the height (and therefore the rise) of the cornbread at the edge and middle. We looked at the browning and crust on the edges and underside of each cornbread.</p><p><strong>Steak:</strong> We based our steak testing on <a href=\"https://www.seriouseats.com/perfect-pan-seared-steaks-recipe\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored\">this recipe</a> from Serious Eats. We seared New York strip steak by heating canola oil until smoking, placing the steak in the center of the plan, and flipping repeatedly for 6 to 10 minutes, depending on the thickness of the steak. The best seared steaks have a deep brown crust that is visible from the side of the steak when you cut into it.&#160;</p><p><strong>Eggs:</strong> Our last test was to make a sunny side-up egg in the middle of the pan with less than half a teaspoon of butter. We did this last to give the skillets a chance to develop a bit of seasoning. We looked for the egg to slide off the pan without breaking or sticking.</p><p><strong>Maintenance:&#160;</strong>Before and after each cooking test, we cleaned the skillets according to the manufacturers' instructions. We noted if it was difficult to remove stuck food and if the texture of the surface changed after scrubbing. Seasoned cast iron is smooth and semi-glossy; after all three tests, we evaluated each pan for these qualities to indicate a well-seasoned surface.</p>\n\tWhat we look forward to testing\n\t\n\t<p><strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/reviews/out?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.williams-sonoma.com%2Fproducts%2Ffinex-fry-pan\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored\">Finex 10\" Fry Pan:</a> </strong>This pan has two unique features compared to the others we tested. First, the pan is an octagon, so you can pour from any direction. Second, the stainless steel spring handle is supposed to stay cooler than traditional cast iron handles. We are curious not only to see how this pan performs, but also if either of these design features makes a difference.</p><p><strong><a href=\"https://go.skimresources.com?id=35871X943606&#38;xs=1&#38;url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.potsandpans.com%2Fcollections%2Fayesha-curry%2Fproducts%2F12-inch-preseasoned-cast-iron-skillet-with-helper-handle\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"nofollow noopener sponsored\">Ayesha Curry Pre-Seasoned 12\" Cast Iron Skillet:</a></strong> Though larger than the pans we previously tested, we are interested in testing this Ayesha Curry pan. The 12-inch pan is under $50, offering more cooking surface for less than our top pick. Additionally, this is a new release as of September 2021 for the Ayesha Curry line.&#160;&#160;</p>\n\tFAQs\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6154910d2fb46b0019be9a82?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Seared steak in the Zest Cast Iron Skillet, one of the cast iron pans we tested.\" height=\"3024\" width=\"4032\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Lily Alig/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<h3 class=\"faq-question\">How do you clean/wash cast iron?</h3><p class=\"faq-answer\">What you've heard isn't true: you can use soap on cast iron, but it should be sparingly. Most importantly, do not soak your cast iron and make sure it is completely dry when you store it. McArthur says she will heat the pan up over a low light to make sure there is no moisture before putting it away. This is a popular way to prevent rust, shared by Bernstein, Pasternak, and multiple manufacturers of the pans we tested.</p><p class=\"faq-answer\">All the pans we tested came with specific cleaning instructions, so we recommend consulting that information before using your skillet.&#160;</p><hr /><h3 class=\"faq-question\">How do you season cast iron?</h3><p class=\"faq-answer\">The easiest way to season a cast iron pan is to use it, initially with a fair amount of cooking oil. The layer of seasoning is actually oil cooked onto the cast iron surface, a process called polymerization, McArthur said. So, the more you cook on the pan, the more oil is absorbed by the surface, and the more nonstick your pan becomes.&#160;</p><p class=\"faq-answer\">Even if the pan is pre-seasoned, we found most will still take a few cooking sessions to become truly nonstick. After you wash the pan, McArthur, Pasternak, and Bernstein all recommend coating your completely dry skillet with cooking oil. This helps preserve the seasoning.</p><hr /><h3 class=\"faq-question\">Is cast iron compatible with an induction stovetop?</h3><p class=\"faq-answer\">One of the beauties of cast iron cookware is that it can be used almost anywhere. You can place your skillet on the grill, in the oven, or on an induction stovetop. Always consult the manufacturer's instructions before using your cookware, especially regarding oven safe temperatures.</p>\n\tRead our stories on how to properly care for cast iron cookware\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5a3140f54aa6b5a01a8b45b6?format=jpeg\" alt=\"lodge cast iron\" height=\"686\" width=\"914\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Lodge</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<ul class=\"summary-list\"><li><strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-clean-cast-iron-pan-skillet-cookware\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">How to clean cast iron</a></strong></li><li><strong><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-to-season-cast-iron-pan-skillet-cookware\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\">How to season cast iron</a>&#160;</strong></li></ul>\n</div><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/best-cast-iron-skillet'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=vzunNrd5YUo:fiX0juCZwwc:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a _2/2021/10/01/02-08-33-623_4cfa42421b1500ca.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/vzunNrd5YUo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn36@2020_4/2021/10/01/02-08-30-341_de63c85a784bc65e.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1633054085849},{"createdTime":"2021-10-01 10:08:05","updatedTime":"2021-10-01 10:08:05","title":"Critics point to Kyrsten Sinema post calling for corporations to 'pay their fair share' of taxes","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/kyrsten-sinema-deletes-post-calling-for-tax-hikes-rich-corporations-2021-9","description":"<figure> \n <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/60dc80eca08b100012b41734?format=jpeg\" alt=\"U.S. Sen. Kirsten Sinema (D-AZ) heads back to a bipartisan meeting on infrastructure in the basement of the U.S. Capitol building after the original talks fell through with the White House on June 8, 2021 in Washington, DC.\" height=\"1000\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\"> \n  <figcaption>\n   U.S. Sen. Kirsten Sinema (D-AZ) heads back to a bipartisan meeting on infrastructure in the basement of the U.S. Capitol building after the original talks fell through with the White House on June 8, 2021 in Washington, DC. Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-NY) said they are now pursuing a two-path proposal that includes a new set of negotiations with a bipartisan group of senators. \n   <p class=\"copyright\">Samuel Corum/Getty Images</p> \n  </figcaption> </img>\n</figure>\n<ul class=\"summary-list\"> \n <li>Sen. Kyrsten Sinema was elected to the US Senate in 2018.</li> \n <li>Before being elected, Sinema advocated raising taxes on corporations and wealthy Americans.</li> \n <li>But Sinema, a former member of the Green Party, has become more conservative in recent years.</li> \n <li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider's business page</a>.</li> \n</ul>\n<p>US Sen. Kyrsten Sinema has told colleagues she opposes raising taxes on corporations and wealthy Americans as part of President Joe Biden and congressional Democrats' $3.5 trillion spending proposal, The New York Times reported this week.</p>\n<p>But the Democrat from Arizona, who once served as a spokesperson for the left-wing Green Party, didn't always object to making corporations and the rich \"pay their fair share.\"</p>\n<p>In a 2011 post on Twitter, Sinema - then a member of the Arizona state Senate - said doing so was only \"common sense.\"</p>\n<figure> \n <img src=\"https://i.insider.com/61560c497b09e80018e59ddc?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Twitter post from Kyrsten Sinema\" height=\"260\" width=\"1066\" charset=\"\"> \n  <figcaption>\n   Sinema deleted this post on September 30, 2021. \n   <p class=\"copyright\">Screenshot/Twitter</p> \n  </figcaption> </img>\n</figure>\n<p>Sinema's liberal critics began pointing to that comment on Thursday. \"So you're voting for Build Back Better, then?\" <a href=\"https://twitter.com/Karoli/status/1443651340538810373\">asked Karoli Kuns</a>, managing editor of the progressive blog Crooks and Liars.</p>\n<p>Sinema's murky opposition to her fellow Democrats' reconciliation proposal, which would expand Medicare, cut tuition at community colleges, and extend the child tax credit has threatened its passage in a chamber where the party can not afford to lose a single vote. While she has balked at the price tag, she has not explicitly detailed her objections, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/progressives-are-furious-at-sen-kyrsten-sinemas-opposition-to-biden-agenda-2021-9\">angering progressives</a>.</p>\n<p>Back in Arizona, leaders of the state Democratic Party have threatened to hold a \"<a href=\"https://ktar.com/story/4706697/arizona-democratic-party-threatens-sen-sinema-with-no-confidence-vote/\">no confidence</a>\" vote if she delays or votes against the $3.5 trillion package.</p>\n<p><em>Have a news tip? Email this reporter: <a href=\"mailto:cdavis@insider.com\">cdavis@insider.com</a></em></p>\n<p><em>This post has been updated.</em></p>\n<div class=\"read-original\">\n Read the original article on \n 2021 19:42:00 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/60dc80e0a08b100012b41733?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"abe8a8163c9a9c10f5b3faa0da876bdd","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn88@2020_1/2021/10/01/02-08-29-707_8e89d7b32db49151.webp","destWidth":1777,"destHeight":1333,"sourceBytes":110224,"destBytes":110224,"author":"cdavis@insider.com (Charles Davis)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/60dc80eca08b100012b41734?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn3@2020_6/2021/10/01/02-08-33-763_3a949b00c6e88d2c.webp","https://i.insider.com/61560c497b09e80018e59ddc?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn59@2020_3/2021/10/01/02-08-32-452_ea86d6454b8f22cf.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn83@2020_1/2021/10/01/02-08-34-915_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=ZtjcvRxSEoI:Owup1RjA9WI:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn83@2020_4/2021/10/01/02-08-35-893_d5fba37a706d8541.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=ZtjcvRxSEoI:Owup1RjA9WI:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn24@2020_4/2021/10/01/02-08-34-456_d200868be596d2f9.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn99@2020_6/2021/10/01/02-08-33-043_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=ZtjcvRxSEoI:Owup1RjA9WI:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn44@2020_6/2021/10/01/02-08-32-112_1e041d0f3b3884b8.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/ZtjcvRxSEoI":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn79@2020_6/2021/10/01/02-08-36-246_7ca40bad7c0ffc10.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1633054085735},{"createdTime":"2021-10-01 10:08:05","updatedTime":"2021-10-01 10:08:05","title":"Hollywood holds its breath as blockbuster hopefuls like 'No Time to Die' and 'Dune' test the limits of movie-theater recovery","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/hollywood-faces-a-major-test-in-october-2021-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6154fc7db414c100186304de?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Tom Hardy looking at Venom\" height=\"2574\" width=\"4576\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Tom Hardy in &#34;Venom: Let There Be Carnage.&#34;\n<p class=\"copyright\">Sony</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Multiple big movie releases are packed into October, from &#34;Venom: Let There Be Carnage&#34; to &#34;Dune.&#34;</li>\n<li>The month will test whether the US theatrical market can sustain so many tentpole films.</li>\n<li>Some Hollywood releases will also open in China after &#34;Shang-Chi&#34; was shut out, but the real test will come later.</li>\n<li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider&#39;s business page</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>After multiple delays, some of Hollywood&#39;s biggest movies of the year will finally see the light of day in October.</p><p>But their triumph isn&#39;t guaranteed in a theatrical market damaged by the pandemic, even after the success of Marvel&#39;s &#34;Shang-Chi and the Legend of the Ten Rings,&#34; which has grossed nearly $200 million domestically and become <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-shang-chi-became-biggest-movie-at-us-box-office-2021-9\">the highest-grossing movie this year in the US</a> since debuting on September 3. </p><p>Hollywood is about to find out whether domestic movie theaters can sustain multiple tentpole releases in a row. It will also find out if audiences in China, which passed the US last year as the world&#39;s biggest cinema market, are craving foreign blockbusters at a pivotal moment for Hollywood and China&#39;s relationship.</p><p>Some of October&#39;s most high-profile releases include:</p><ul><li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/wall-street-undervalues-sony-hollywood-powerhouse-spider-man-venom-2021-9\">Sony</a>&#39;s &#34;Venom: Let There Be Carnage&#34; - in US theaters October 1</li><li>MGM&#39;s &#34;No Time to Die&#34; - in US theaters October 8/in China October 29</li><li>Universal&#39;s &#34;Halloween Kills&#34; - in US theaters and on Peacock October 15</li><li>Warner Bros.&#39; &#34;Dune&#34; - in US/China theaters and on HBO Max October 22</li></ul><p>The month will also see the release of The &#34;Sopranos&#34; prequel &#34;The Many Saints of Newark&#34; in theaters and on Max this weekend and Ridley Scott&#39;s &#34;The Last Duel&#34; on October 15.</p><p>Needless to say, it will be a big month for movies - maybe. It all depends on whether audience turnout prevails over lingering concerns about the coronavirus and day-and-date streaming strategies.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/613745f6eedea900193d4e72?format=jpeg\" alt=\"A picture of Timothée Chalamet and Rebecca Ferguson in &#34;Dune.&#34;\" height=\"675\" width=\"1200\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Timothée Chalamet and Rebecca Ferguson in &#34;Dune.&#34;\n<p class=\"copyright\">Warner Bros.</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><h2>Theaters are inching toward recovery</h2><p>&#34;Shang-Chi&#34; proved there is still an appetite for going to movie theaters. But the movie has faced little competition since opening earlier this month. Even some of the summer&#39;s best performing films at the domestic box office - from &#34;A Quiet Place Part II&#34; to &#34;F9&#34; to &#34;Black Widow&#34; - were spread out.</p><p>Theater owners believe the secret to success is twofold: actually releasing films, and then making them exclusive to theaters.</p><p>&#34;Studios&#39; choices are: get a decent return on your movies now, take them straight to streaming and sacrifice all of the box office, or keep delaying until the industry dies,&#34; the National Association of Theater Owners (NATO) chief John Fithian <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/theater-association-chief-movie-delays-could-kill-industry-2021-8\">told Insider in a recent interview</a>.</p><p>Fithian predicted that &#34;Shang-Chi&#34; would have stronger legs at the box office than &#34;Black Widow,&#34; which Disney released simultaneously to theaters and Disney+. The numbers suggest he was right. </p><p>But what happens in October will tell Hollywood whether all of those aforementioned films - even those exclusive to theaters like &#34;Let There Be Carnage&#34; and &#34;No Time to Die&#34; - can thrive when packed into one month, in a market where even some of the most successful big-budget tentpoles have failed to reach pre-pandemic levels of success.</p><p>If they are successful, Hollywood may feel more confident about releasing its remaining scheduled films this year. If not, movie-studio execs may go back to the drawing board and either consider delaying films again, such as Paramount did with &#34;Top Gun: Maverick,&#34; or releasing them simultaneously to streaming and theaters.</p><p>Here&#39;s how those movies&#39; predecessors fared at the box office:</p><ul><li>&#34;Spectre&#34; (2015) - $880 million globally/$200 million domestically/$70 million opening weekend</li><li>&#34;Venom&#34; (2018) - $856 million globally/$215 million domestically/$80 million opening weekend</li><li>&#34;Halloween&#34; (2018) - $255 million globally/$159 million domestically/$76 million opening weekend</li></ul><p>While movie studios have tempered their expectations during the pandemic, those numbers still put a lot of pressure on these movies to perform at a respectable level - especially &#34;No Time to Die,&#34; with its massive $250 million budget. Foreign markets can pick up the slack, as they did before the pandemic, but the biggest foreign market may not be as reliable for Hollywood as it once was.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e57d0c1fee23d37c7514919?format=jpeg\" alt=\"no time to die\" height=\"858\" width=\"1246\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Daniel Craig as James Bond in &#34;No Time to Die&#34;\n<p class=\"copyright\">MGM</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><h2>China is a big question mark </h2><p>Before the pandemic, Hollywood relied on China - then the No. 2 theatrical market - to boost its blockbusters on the global scale. But the comeback story in the region has been more about China&#39;s own film industry.</p><p>So far this year, only two Hollywood releases are currently in the top 10 at China&#39;s box office: &#34;F9&#34; and &#34;Godzilla vs. Kong.&#34; Since the pandemic, which China&#39;s theater industry has recovered from more quickly than in the US, local Chinese films have performed exceptionally well, at levels Hollywood film studios can only dream of right now.</p><p>And &#34;No Time to Die&#34; and &#34;Dune&#34; could leave Hollywood still holding its breath.</p><p>The films could face issues at the China box office, according to Stanley Rosen, a political science professor at the University of Southern California who specializes in Chinese politics and cinema.</p><p>&#34;No Time to Die&#34; will get released in North America and other international markets before China (and the James Bond franchise isn&#39;t a staple in the region; &#34;Spectre&#34; earned $83 million there). And &#34;Dune&#34; will stream simultaneously on HBO Max. Both situations invite piracy, which Rosen said is a &#34;big issue in China.&#34;</p><p>But he said the real test for Hollywood in the region is Marvel.</p><p>China has shut out &#34;Black Widow&#34; and &#34;Shang-Chi,&#34; depriving Hollywood of a chance to see if the Marvel brand, which traditionally performs well in the region, can still do so. (&#34;Avengers: Endgame&#34; is China&#39;s highest-grossing foreign release ever.)</p><p>The next Marvel movie, &#34;Eternals,&#34; also faces release challenges due to past comments made by director Chloé Zhao, who was born in China, and said &#34;there are lies everywhere&#34; in the country in a 2013 interview. Rosen is optimistic about the movie&#39;s chances, though, even given the Zhao controversy.</p><p>&#34;China wants to be the largest film market in the world and COVID did that for them,&#34; he said. &#34;But you have to keep some Hollywood product because people want them.&#34;</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/hollywood-faces-a-major-test-in-october-2021-9'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=pBPbTB1upV8:SU55qeXSh7o:F7zBnMyn0Lo\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=pBPbTB1upV8:SU55qeXSh7o:F7zBnMyn0Lo\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=pBPbTB1upV8:SU55qeXSh7o:V_sGLiPBpWU\"><img border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/pBPbTB1upV8\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Thu, 30 Sep 2021 20:04:12 10:08:05","updatedTime":"2021-10-01 10:08:05","title":"The Fed has 'no intention' to ban cryptocurrencies, Jerome Powell tells Congress","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/fed-has-no-intention-to-ban-cryptocurrencies-powell-tells-congress-2021-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6156075e7b09e80018e59c15?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Jerome Powell Senate Banking testimony\" height=\"2635\" width=\"5270\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Kevin Lamarque/Reuters</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul><li><strong>Fed Chairman Jerome Powell told Congress that the central bank has &#34;no intention&#34; to ban cryptocurrencies.</strong></li><li><strong>The answer came in response to a question from House Representative Ted Budd of North Carolina.</strong></li><li><strong>But Powell also said stablecoins need to be regulated, calling them similar to money market funds.</strong></li><li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://newsletter.businessinsider.com/join/4np/10-things-opening-bell?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingest?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingest?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingest?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingest?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingest?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingest?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingest?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingest?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingest?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingest?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingest?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingest?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingest?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingestm_medium=ingest?utm_source=markets&#38;utm_medium=ingest\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\"><strong>Sign up here for our daily newsletter, 10 Things Before the Opening Bell</strong></a><strong>.</strong></li></ul><hr><p>The long-held belief of cryptocurrency bears that the US government will outright ban the sector, akin to the government making it illegal to hold gold in 1933, was put to the test on Thursday.</p><p>Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell <a href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/videos/2021-09-30/powell-says-fed-has-no-intention-to-ban-cryptocurrencies-video\">testified to Congress</a> on Thursday that the central bank has &#34;no intention&#34; to ban cryptocurrencies. The answer came in response to a question from House Representative Ted Budd of North Carolina.</p><p>&#34;As a matter of policy, is it your intention to ban or limit the use of cryptocurrencies like we&#39;re seeing in China?&#34; Budd asked Powell.</p><p>Powell responded, &#34;No intention to ban [them].&#34;</p><p>That&#39;s not to say Powell thinks they should avoid regulation, which <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/currencies/sec-crypto-gary-gensler-regulation-trading-platforms-rules-oversight-2021-9\">SEC Chairman Gary Gensler</a> has urged. Powell pointed to stablecoins in particular, calling them similar to money market funds, which need to be regulated.</p><p>&#34;Stablecoins are like money market funds, are like bank deposits, but they&#39;re to some extent outside the regulatory perimeter and it&#39;s appropriate that they be regulated. Same activity, same regulation,&#34; Powell said.</p><p>The comments come as the Fed continues to <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/currencies/federal-reserve-central-bank-digital-currency-cbdc-research-report-summer-2021-5\">study the potential use cases of a central bank digital currency</a> similar to cryptocurrencies. </p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a 10:08:05","updatedTime":"2021-10-01 10:08:05","title":"Dow falls 546 points as consumer stocks dragged by supply-chain worries to close 3rd quarter","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/stock-market-news-500-dow-nasdaq-q3-consumer-september-markets-2021-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6155d9827b09e80018e58b23?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Traders work on the floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, U.S., October 9, 2019. REUTERS/Brendan McDermid\" height=\"3083\" width=\"6166\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Traders work on the floor at the NYSE in New York.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Reuters</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Major stock indexes turned lower to close in the red Thursday. The Dow was down nearly 550 points.</li>\n<li>Consumer stocks dropped as supply-chain worries hit shares of Bed Bath &#38; Beyond and Kohl&#39;s. </li>\n<li>Wall Street&#39;s major indexes dropped in September.</li>\n<li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider&#39;s business page</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>All three major indexes ended lower Thursday as worries about global supply-chain problems contributed to a decline in consumer stocks, though the S&#38;P 500 managed to notch a modest win for the third quarter. </p><p>The S&#38;P 500 and the Dow each ended lower, with retailing stocks hurt after <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/stocks/bbby-stock\">Bed Bath &#38; Beyond </a>cut its <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/bed-bath-beyond-stock-price-q2-earnings-profit-outlook-guidance-2021-9\">yearly sales outlook</a> and <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/stocks/kss-stock\">Kohl&#39;s</a> suffered a double <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/kohls-stock-price-bank-of-america-downgrades-sell-supply-chain-2021-9\">ratings downgrade at Bank of America to underperform</a>. Shares in each company plunged.  The Dow fell nearly 550 points. </p><p>The S&#38;P 500 pulled out a slight quarterly gain but suffered in September, its first monthly loss this year. The Dow and the Nasdaq dropped for the month. </p><p><strong>Here&#39;s where US indexes stood at 4:00 p.m. on Thursday:  </strong></p><ul><li aria-level=\"1\"><strong><a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/index/s&p_500?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingest?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingestedium=ingest\">S&#38;P 500</a>: </strong>4,307.54, down 1.19%</li></ul><ul><li aria-level=\"1\"><strong><a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/index/dow_jones?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingest?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingestm=ingest\">Dow Jones Industrial Average</a>: </strong>33,843.92, down 1.59% (546.80 points)</li></ul><ul><li aria-level=\"1\"><strong><a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/index/nasdaq_composite?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingest?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingestm=ingest\">Nasdaq Composite</a>: </strong>14,448.58, down 0.44%</li></ul><p>The S&#38;P 500&#39;s consumer staples and discretionary indexes were among the worst-performing as backed up shipping ports and other supply bottlenecks affecting nearly all industries cropped back into focus for retail stocks. BofA said a sales recovery at Kohl&#39;s may be threatened by snarled supply chains and Bed Bath &#38; Beyond cited that issue, rising costs, and resurgent COVID-19 fears as pressure points for its business. </p><p><a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/stocks/hd-stock\">Home Depot</a> fell on the Dow index and <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/stocks/tgt-stock\">Target</a>, which it says is the <a href=\"https://corporate.target.com/article/2021/09/supply-chain-prep\">second-largest importer in the US</a>, also declined. </p><p>From the labor market, weekly jobless claims reported early Thursday rose to 362,000, a third straight increase that missed the 335,000 consensus estimate from Econoday. But the Federal Reserve may still be on course to start reducing purchases of Treasury and mortgage-backed securities from $120 billion a month. </p><p>&#34;We remain focused on the evolution of monetary policy and expect the Federal Reserve to lay out the pace and timing of adjustments to the bond purchase program (tapering) in the fourth quarter as they weigh recent inflation readings against the longer-term goal of price stability,&#34; said Bill Northey, senior investment director at U.S. Bank Wealth Management, in a note to Insider.</p><p>Around the markets, billionaire investor Chamath Palihapitiya has invested millions of dollars into <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/currencies/btc-usd?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingestgest\">bitcoin</a> and believes it&#39;s <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/currencies/chamath-palihapitiya-bitcoin-holdings-crypto-hard-to-kill-regulation-2021-9\">tough to impose a blanket ban</a> on cryptocurrencies, he said CNBC. </p><p>The US network of bitcoin ATMs <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/currencies/bitcoin-atms-hacks-crypto-vulnerable-exchange-kraken-report-2021-9\">is vulnerable to hacks</a>, says crypto exchange Kraken. </p><p><a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/commodities/gold-price?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingest?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingestm=ingest\">Gold</a> rose 1.8% to $1,757.80 per ounce. Oil prices turned higher, with<a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/commodities/oil-price?type=wti?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingest?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingestm=ingest\"> West Texas Intermediate crude</a> up 0.6% to $75.25 per barrel.</p><p><a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/currencies/btc-usd\">Bitcoin</a> jumped 5.2% to $43,664.59. </p><p> </p><div on the temples, these classic sunglasses won't look out of place no matter where they go or what they pair them with.&#160;</p>\n\tAn insulated tumbler to keep their drinks hot or cool\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5d716de82e22af0a3051e3e9?format=jpeg\" alt=\"mickey tumbler\" height=\"900\" width=\"1200\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Amazon</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><strong><a insulation, this tumbler will keep their drinks hot for up to eight hours and cold for up to 24 hours. Plus, they'll get to revisit all their favorite Mickeys through the years when sipping on their morning brew.</p>\n\tA Mickey and Friends graphic tee\n\t<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f71fe210ab50d00184acc48?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Disney gifts tshirt\" height=\"900\" width=\"1200\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p list, here's a perfectly worn-in style they can easily pair with jeans on the weekend or Mickey ears in Magic Kingdom.&#160;</p>\n\tA Mickey Mouse watch they'll actually want to look at to tell the class=\"copyright\">Nixon/Instagram</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure>\n\t<p><strong><a accessory for a Disney fan &#8212; and not just one they'll want to wear once on a trip to the park.</p>\n</div><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a
