yreaderx15/cdn92@2020_5/2021/10/01/02-08-35-193_bc4e50fe7a637c6c.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f71fe210ab50d00184acc48?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn91@2020_1/2021/10/01/02-08-35-730_cd16d455c879e5ea.webp","https://i.insider.com/5d604ecc46552c02464989f3?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn21@2020_6/2021/10/01/02-08-11-345_0e8b9bd852724dcf.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn83@2020_1/2021/10/01/02-08-34-915_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=4zibHELK0jE:FMUzvml4pZY:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn11@2020_1/2021/10/01/02-08-33-806_71e376cc0cddd140.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=4zibHELK0jE:FMUzvml4pZY:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn91@2020_5/2021/10/01/02-08-32-208_90564481e4aa497d.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn99@2020_6/2021/10/01/02-08-33-043_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=4zibHELK0jE:FMUzvml4pZY:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn68@2020_5/2021/10/01/02-08-33-970_192e4d4f8c07fbee.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/4zibHELK0jE":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn67@2020_4/2021/10/01/02-08-31-608_059d47fe339c5bda.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1633054085951},{"createdTime":"2021-10-01 10:08:05","updatedTime":"2021-10-01 10:08:05","title":"Frontier Airlines announced 12 new routes with a focus on Cancun and Tampa - see the full list","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/frontier-airline-targets-cancun-tampa-in-latest-network-expansion-2021-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6155cdf57b09e80018e587f4?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Frontier Airlines Airbus A321\" height=\"2524\" width=\"3365\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A Frontier Airlines Airbus A321\n<p class=\"copyright\">Carlos Yudica/Shutterstock.com</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Frontier announced 12 new routes in its latest network expansion, focusing on Mexico and Florida.</li>\n<li>Cancun will get six new routes beginning in December and Tampa will get five beginning in November.</li>\n<li>The airline will offer introductory fares starting at $39 one-way to Tampa and $89 one-way to Cancun.</li>\n<li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider&#39;s business page</a>.</li>\n</ul><p><a href=\"https://www.flyfrontier.com/deals/sales/introsale?utm_source=facebook&utm_medium=social&utm_campaign=organic%20social_newroutes_9.28.21_9.28.21\">Frontier Airlines announced</a> 12 new routes on Wednesday and it&#39;s honing in on Mexico and Florida, just in time for the winter travel season.</p><p>Frontier is targeting Cancun, Mexico, and Tampa, Florida in its latest network expansion, with service scheduled to start on November 30. Five nonstop routes will operate to Tampa International Airport, six to Cancun International Airport, and the last of the 12 will connect Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport and Punta Cana International Airport in the Dominican Republic.</p><blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet blockquote\" data-lang=\"en\" data-cards=\"\" data-conversation=\"\">-Frontier Airlines  (@FlyFrontier) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/mims/statuses/1442912939573268480?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">September 28, 2021</a></blockquote><script async=\"\" src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script><p> </p><p><a href=\"https://news.flyfrontier.com/frontier-airlines-announces-new-crew-base-in-tampa-and-future-plans-to-establish-atlanta-base/\">Frontier made Tampa a crew base in May 2021</a> and intends to establish Atlanta as a base later this year, according to the airline. The carrier said nearly 400 pilots and flight attendants would be based in Tampa and that the opening of both bases will give it the opportunity to increase its domestic and international operations out of the growing markets.</p><p><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/leisure-travel-coming-back-experts-business-travel-recovery-years-out-2021-7\">With business travel lagging</a>, a bulk of the pandemic rebound has come from tourists heading to leisure destinations, and Frontier&#39;s focus on Cancun and Tampa banks on traveler demand for beach vacations.</p><p>&#34;We&#39;re excited to grow in our newest base city, Tampa, with five new nonstop routes beginning right in time for the winter travel season. Tampa continues to shine, literally and figuratively, as a destination people want to visit, especially in the winter months,&#34; said Daniel Shurtz, Frontier&#39;s senior vice president of commercial.</p><p>However, after a strong summer season, some airlines say end-of-year bookings are down due to the continued threat of the Delta variant, which is causing travelers to postpone or cancel plans. Andrew Nocella, United Airlines&#39; chief marketing officer, said during an investor conference in early September that he anticipates travel to slump in October, November, and between Thanksgiving and Christmas, <a href=\"https://www.usatoday.com/story/travel/airline-news/2021/09/09/fall-travel-airlines-covid-ticket-sales-bookings/8264554002/\">reported USA Today</a>.</p><p>Nevertheless, <a href=\"https://newsroom.expedia.com/2021-09-29-Holiday-Travel-Forecast-Expedia-Reveals-the-Top-Trending-Destinations\">data released by Expedia</a> on Wednesday revealed the top trending winter destinations for this holiday season, and Cancun was number two for Christmas, which is right when Frontier is launching its new routes. Also on the list was Punta Cana at number five and the Sarasota area, which is just south of Tampa, at number 10. </p><p>Here&#39;s a closer look at Frontier&#39;s 12 new routes.</p><h2>Between Tampa and Rochester, New York</h2><h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6155df40b414c1001863192d?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Rochester\" height=\"1414\" width=\"1885\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Rochester, New York\n<p class=\"copyright\">Roland Shainidze Photogaphy/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure></h2><p>Frontier will fly thrice-weekly to Rochester on Tuesdays, Thursdays, and Saturdays beginning November 30. The route will see competition from Southwest Airlines, which is scheduled to begin Saturday-only service between the two cities from mid-December. One-way introductory fares start at $49.</p><h2>Between Tampa and New York City</h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/60db59241477f300188c859e?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Buildings in Manhattan as seen from the tall One Vanderbilt building against a blue sky.\" height=\"1875\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>New York City, New York\n<p class=\"copyright\">Joey Hadden/Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Frontier will fly twice-weekly to New York&#39;s LaGuardia Airport on Mondays and Wednesdays beginning December 1. The airline will compete with a number of airlines, including JetBlue, Delta, Spirit, and Southwest. One-way introductory fares start at $39.</p><h2>Between Tampa and Bloomington, Illinois</h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6155ea1c7b09e80018e5910f?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Bloomington Illinois\" height=\"1333\" width=\"1777\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Bloomington, Illinois\n<p class=\"copyright\">Henryk Sadura/Shutterstock</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Frontier will fly twice-weekly to Bloomington on Mondays and Fridays beginning December 17. The carrier will offer the only nonstop service between the two cities, meaning no direct competition. However, Allegiant operates a route to Bloomington from nearby St. Pete-Clearwater International Airport, which is only 20 minutes from Tampa. One-way introductory fares start at $49.</p><h2>Between Tampa and Green Bay, Wisconsin</h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6155ea29b414c10018631dc0?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Green Bay Wisconsin\" height=\"1125\" width=\"1500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Green Bay, Wisconsin\n<p class=\"copyright\">JamesBrey/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Frontier will fly twice-weekly to Green Bay on Thursdays and Sundays beginning December 16. The airline will not face direct competition on the route, however, Allegiant operates nonstop service between the secondary cities of St. Petersburg in Florida, which is 20 minutes from Tampa, and Appleton in Wisconsin, which is 40 minutes from Green Bay. One-way introductory fares at $49.</p><h2>Tampa to Columbus, Ohio</h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6022ea88cca90200129b74cf?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Columbus ohio\" height=\"1413\" width=\"1884\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Columbus, Ohio\n<p class=\"copyright\">pawel.gaul/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Frontier will fly twice-weekly to Columbus on Mondays and Wednesdays beginning December 17. The carrier will see competition from Spirit, Southwest, and newcomer Breeze Airways, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/what-its-like-to-fly-on-jetblue-founder-david-neelemans-breeze-airways-2021-5\">which just launched operations in May</a>. Moreover, Allegiant operates a route from nearby St. Pete-Clearwater to Columbus&#39; secondary airport, Rickenbacker International Airport, which is 25 minutes away from Columbus&#39; primary airport where Frontier flies. One-way introductory fares start at $49.</p><h2>Between Boston and Cancun</h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6155ea5d7b09e80018e59125?format=jpeg\" alt=\"boston skyline\" height=\"3639\" width=\"4853\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Boston, Massachusettes\n<p class=\"copyright\">Getty/Steve Marsel</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Frontier will fly five-times-weekly from Boston to Cancun on Mondays, Tuesdays, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Saturdays beginning December 16. The route will face competition from JetBlue, Delta, and American, which offers Saturday-only service. One-way introductory fares start at $89.</p><h2>Between Minneapolis and Cancun</h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6155ea77b414c10018631de7?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Minneapolis Skyline\" height=\"2828\" width=\"3770\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Minneapolis, Minnesota\n<p class=\"copyright\"><a href=\"https://www.shutterstock.com/image-photo/minneapolis-minnesota-downtown-stone-arch-bridge-211600999\" target=\"_blank\">Scruggelgreen/Shutterstock</a></p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Frontier will fly five-times-weekly from Minneapolis to Cancun on Mondays, Tuesdays, Wednesdays, Thursdays, and Saturdays beginning December 16. The airline will compete with Delta and Sun Country on the route. One-way introductory fares start at $89.</p><h2>Between Baltimore and Cancun</h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6155ea8cb414c10018631def?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Baltimore city skyline\" height=\"713\" width=\"950\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Baltimore, Maryland\n<p class=\"copyright\">Shutterstock</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Frontier will fly thrice-weekly from Baltimore to Cancun on Mondays, Wednesdays, and Saturdays beginning December 17. The route will see competition from Spirit and Southwest. One-way introductory fares start at $89.</p><h2>Between Detroit and Cancun</h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6155eaa07b09e80018e5913c?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Detroit skyline\" height=\"1487\" width=\"1982\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Detroit, Michigan\n<p class=\"copyright\">Rebecca Cook/Reuters</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Frontier will fly twice-weekly from Detroit to Cancun on Tuesdays and Thursdays beginning December 16. Delta and Spirit will be direct competitors on this route. One-way introductory fares start at $89.</p><h2>Between Columbus, Ohio and Cancun</h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f5a3aaae6ff30001d4e7ff5?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Cancun, Mexico\" height=\"1403\" width=\"1872\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Cancun, Mexico\n<p class=\"copyright\">Shutterstock.com</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Frontier will fly twice-weekly from Columbus to Cancun on Mondays and Fridays beginning January 21. The airline will face Saturday-only competition from American and Southwest. One-way introductory fares start at $89.</p><h2>Between Raleigh-Durham, North Carolina and Cancun</h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6155eb20b414c10018631e2d?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Raleigh, North Carolina\" height=\"664\" width=\"886\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Raleigh, North Carolina\n<p class=\"copyright\">Kevin Ruck/Shutterstock</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Frontier will fly once weekly from Raleigh-Durham to Cancun on Saturdays beginning January 22. American and JetBlue will be competitors on the route. One-way introductory fares start at $89.</p><h2>Between Atlanta and Punta Cana, Dominican Republic</h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5f5a3b7b7ed0ee001e25e7a3?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Punta Cana, Dominican Republic\" height=\"1665\" width=\"2220\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Punta Cana, Dominican Republic\n<p class=\"copyright\">Shutterstock.com</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Frontier will fly once weekly from Atlanta to Punta Cana on Saturdays beginning December 18. The carrier will compete with Delta on the route. One-way introductory fares start at $99.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/frontier-airline-targets-cancun-tampa-in-latest-network-expansion-2021-9'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=eorRMhF5u6E:-UCUblcnB-I:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=eorRMhF5u6E:-UCUblcnB-I:F7zBnMyn0Lo\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=eorRMhF5u6E:-UCUblcnB-I:F7zBnMyn0Lo\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=eorRMhF5u6E:-UCUblcnB-I:V_sGLiPBpWU\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=eorRMhF5u6E:-UCUblcnB-I:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=eorRMhF5u6E:-UCUblcnB-I:qj6IDK7rITs\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=eorRMhF5u6E:-UCUblcnB-I:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=eorRMhF5u6E:-UCUblcnB-I:gIN9vFwOqvQ\" border=\"0\"></img></a>\n</div><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/eorRMhF5u6E\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\"/>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Thu, 30 Sep 2021 20:57:48 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/6155ed157b09e80018e59212?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"7c076b7897b8140aeffe1cdfbcbd4f1d","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn11@2020_5/2021/10/01/02-08-58-072_28dddc982d9b84a4.webp","destWidth":4007,"destHeight":3005,"sourceBytes":116404,"destBytes":116404,"author":"trains@insider.com (Taylor Rains)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/6155cdf57b09e80018e587f4?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn63@2020_3/2021/10/01/02-08-33-797_e464068feacfbcaa.webp","https://i.insider.com/6155df40b414c1001863192d?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn55@2020_5/2021/10/01/02-08-29-926_c86f0a0fd3c339f7.webp","https://i.insider.com/60db59241477f300188c859e?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn71@2020_2/2021/10/01/02-08-34-466_68a5470a6fdacf12.webp","https://i.insider.com/6155ea1c7b09e80018e5910f?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn67@2020_3/2021/10/01/02-08-32-283_760261a15ffda37e.webp","https://i.insider.com/6155ea29b414c10018631dc0?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn17@2020_3/2021/10/01/02-08-34-503_c3fde2b279688161.webp","https://i.insider.com/6022ea88cca90200129b74cf?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn100@2020_3/2021/10/01/02-08-35-952_9879f07d8b2c6494.webp","https://i.insider.com/6155ea5d7b09e80018e59125?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn75@2020_1/2021/10/01/02-08-32-622_4aa1ea87ccce7213.webp","https://i.insider.com/6155ea77b414c10018631de7?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn99@2020_2/2021/10/01/02-08-34-437_f1411eb282784348.webp","https://i.insider.com/6155ea8cb414c10018631def?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn20@2020_1/2021/10/01/02-08-32-594_57b5a439148e275c.webp","https://i.insider.com/6155eaa07b09e80018e5913c?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn35@2020_5/2021/10/01/02-08-33-332_c5fe9cd3fb520514.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f5a3aaae6ff30001d4e7ff5?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn68@2020_3/2021/10/01/02-08-33-695_8ab0883693069fee.webp","https://i.insider.com/6155eb20b414c10018631e2d?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn67@2020_6/2021/10/01/02-08-31-927_5d3735ddedbb1adc.webp","https://i.insider.com/5f5a3b7b7ed0ee001e25e7a3?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn68@2020_4/2021/10/01/02-08-35-486_531dc897da38198e.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn83@2020_1/2021/10/01/02-08-34-915_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=eorRMhF5u6E:-UCUblcnB-I:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn85@2020_4/2021/10/01/02-08-32-373_299683aa9362528f.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=eorRMhF5u6E:-UCUblcnB-I:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn57@2020_5/2021/10/01/02-08-33-550_70b2a722a0681a80.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn99@2020_6/2021/10/01/02-08-33-043_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=eorRMhF5u6E:-UCUblcnB-I:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn56@2020_6/2021/10/01/02-08-35-562_61ff11f5c0dd9f75.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/eorRMhF5u6E":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn87@2020_2/2021/10/01/02-08-34-854_2bc0d6dc07bbeb91.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1633054085711},{"createdTime":"2021-10-01 10:08:05","updatedTime":"2021-10-01 10:08:05","title":"5 ways the debt ceiling brinksmanship in Congress could end, from markets teetering to Biden's agenda and who gets blamed","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/5-ways-the-debt-ceiling-battle-in-congress-could-end-2021-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6155d5187b09e80018e589e6?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-NY) points at Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell as they arrive for a remembrance ceremony marking the 20th anniversary of the 9/11 terror attacks on the steps of the U.S. Capitol, on September 13, 2021 in Washington, DC.\" height=\"1244\" width=\"2488\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Sen. Majority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-NY) and Sen. Minority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-KY).\n<p class=\"copyright\">Drew Angerer/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Even if Congress avoids a shutdown and a default on the nation&#39;s debt, things could still get ugly.</li>\n<li>The brinksmanship fueled by negative polarization entails several knock-on effects.</li>\n<li>Markets could teeter, and it comes at a crucial time for President Biden&#39;s agenda.</li>\n<li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider&#39;s business page</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>As with most things in Congress, seemingly arcane and petty disputes may end up having wide-reaching effects across the American public and global economy.</p><p>When it comes to this particularly chaotic week in late September - with lawmakers in a standoff over lifting the debt ceiling, narrowly avoiding a government shutdown, and making any progress on President Joe Biden&#39;s infrastructure package - the stakes couldn&#39;t be higher and the pettiness is off the charts.</p><p>It might seem irrational given the gravity of the situation, but these inter-connected spats are all <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/fears-of-bernie-sanders-threatening-house-dem-majority-are-overblown-2020-2\">part of a broader trend in American politics known as negative polarization and asymmetric polarization</a>: As long as the other side is losing, your side is winning. That mentality is now especially strong among Republicans with Democrats holding the White House and both chambers of Congress.</p><p>Even if some or all of the following potential catastrophes are averted, the uncertainty and confusion surrounding the negotiations could send global markets teetering in a <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/stock-market-news-today-us-stocks-debt-ceiling-evergrande-infrastructure-2021-9\">ripple effect that may already be under way</a>.</p><p>Here are five ways this Congressional brinksmanship could play out:</p><h2>1. Armageddon: Congress fails to raise the debt ceiling and the US defaults on its debts.</h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6155f057b414c10018632058?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Wall street traders panic\" height=\"1800\" width=\"3600\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange August 9, 2007. \n<p class=\"copyright\">REUTERS/Lucas Jackson</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>The debt limit or debt ceiling is often a misunderstood term, since it pertains to money the US government has already spent, not future payments.</p><p>The Senate and House <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/senate-approves-government-funding-extension-hours-before-shutdown-deadline-2021-9\">have passed</a> a continuing resolution to fund the government and stave off shutdown, averting a double whammy worst-case scenario - but the debt ceiling issue has yet to be resolved.</p><blockquote class=\"twitter-tweet blockquote\" data-lang=\"en\" data-cards=\"\" data-conversation=\"\">-CBS News  (@CBSNews) <a href=\"https://twitter.com/mims/statuses/1443586087415283712?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw\">September 30, 2021</a></blockquote><script async=\"\" src=\"//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js\" charset=\"utf-8\"></script><p> </p><p>If Congress doesn&#39;t lift it, <a href=\"https://www.cnn.com/2021/09/28/economy/debt-ceiling-deadline-yellen/index.html\">the government could run out of funding by mid-October</a>, according to Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen. </p><p>Democrats in the House <a href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2021/09/29/debt-ceiling-pelosi-says-house-will-vote-to-prevent-us-default.html\">passed a bill suspending the debt ceiling, but it was dead on arrival</a> as soon as it reached Senate Republicans. A default - or a near-default - stands to negatively impact markets, and services that millions of Americans reply upon. </p><p>Democrats are sick of dealing with the debt ceiling and the need to regularly stave off economic catastrophe, finding themselves the target of GOP efforts to make them pay a political price via a mechanism that isn&#39;t even used by most developed democracies, as <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/debt-ceiling-democrats-consider-eliminating-limit-government-borrowing-default-recession-2021-9\">Insider&#39;s Ben Winck, Joseph Zeballos-Roig, and Andy Kiersz reported</a> last week.</p><p>Even if there is no default, prolonging the process could still cause a financial drag: The nonpartisan Committee for a Responsible Federal Budget <a href=\"https://www.crfb.org/papers/qa-everything-you-should-know-about-debt-ceiling#_Hlk431978571\">finds</a> that even the threat of default can have &#34;serious negative economic implications.&#34;</p><p>In 2011, a similar showdown resulted in a last-minute increase to the debt ceiling - but not before roiling financial markets as the country&#39;s credit rating was <a href=\"https://money.cnn.com/2011/08/05/news/economy/downgrade_rumors/index.htm\">downgraded</a>. For instance, a Government Accountability Office (GAO) <a href=\"https://www.gao.gov/products/gao-12-701\">report</a> estimated that the prolonged debt ceiling process in 2011 made Treasury&#39;s borrowing costs go up by $1.3 billion.</p><p>There could be a huge hit to employment and stocks if the debt limit doesn&#39;t get lifted by mid-October, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/debt-ceiling-cost-americans-trillions-borrowing-limit-democrats-republicans-moodys-2021-9\">Moody&#39;s Analytics predicts</a>. Economists led by Mark Zandi found that 6 million jobs could be shed, with unemployment soaring up to 9%. Stocks crashing could wipe out $15 trillion in household wealth.</p><p>Yellen said in a <a href=\"https://www.banking.senate.gov/imo/media/doc/Yellen%20Testimony%209-28-21.pdf\">statement</a> to the Committee on Banking, Housing, and Banking that &#34;the full faith and credit of the United States would be impaired, and our country would likely face a financial crisis and economic recession&#34; if the country goes into default.  </p><p>If the debt ceiling isn&#39;t lifted, Americans receiving support from government programs may feel the impact acutely. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen warned in a <a href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/congress-raise-debt-limit-ceiling-yellen-treasury-brinkmanship-federal-budget-11632069056\">Wall Street Journal</a> opinion piece that families could see their monthly child tax credits delayed.</p><p>Also potentially impacted: Military troops, senior citizens, children receiving free or subsidized school lunches, and Americans relying on Medicaid. Yellen wrote that almost 50 million senior citizens may not receive their Social Security checks, and that troops may not receive their paychecks. </p><p>In a memo sent out to the state and local governments, the White House <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/white-house-warning-medicaid-free-school-lunch-cuts-debt-ceiling-2021-9\">warned</a> that federally subsidized Medicaid and free school lunches could face reductions in the case of a default.</p><h2>2. Both crises are avoided and the HIP and BIF live happily ever after.</h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/60a6a33fe25d05001880cb9d?format=jpeg\" alt=\"ilhan omar nancy pelosi\" height=\"1823\" width=\"3647\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Rep. Ilhan Omar (D-MN) (L) and Speaker of the House Nancy Pelosi (D-CA).\n<p class=\"copyright\">Chip Somodevilla/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Because Democrats hold the narrowest majority possible in the Senate, with just 50 members plus Vice President Kamala Harris as the deciding vote, passing Biden&#39;s infrastructure plan has been a high wire act from the start.</p><p>It&#39;s an especially precarious position because it&#39;s so far from the 60 votes needed for most legislation to clear a filibuster from Republicans.</p><p>Given the inevitability of a filibuster on several key Democratic priorities, the bill was split in two: the Bipartisan Infrastructure Framework, or &#34;BIF,&#34; and the more wide-reaching Human Infrastructure Plan, or &#34;HIP.&#34; The ostensible goal was to have enough Republicans vote for the BIF, since it includes more traditional infrastructure components such as roads, bridges, and ports, while the HIP would pass with just the 50 Senate Democrats and VP Harris before going over to the House.</p><p>Right now, Democrats are essentially playing a game of infrastructure chicken as Republicans stand by and watch. From the start, progressives have said that the BIF needs to move in tandem with the larger social spending plan, and <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/aoc-progressives-wont-support-bipartisan-infrastructure-without-reconciliation-2021-7\">have warned</a> they&#39;ll shut down any standalone bipartisan bill. It&#39;s a position that both <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/progressives-bipartisan-infrastructure-reconciliation-bill-together-pelosi-wyden-biden-2021-6\">Biden and Pelosi</a> originally echoed.</p><p>But moderates like Sen. Joe Manchin have indicated that they&#39;re not on board with the <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/joe-manchin-chuck-schumer-reconciliation-agreement-july-trillion-entitlement-society-2021-9\">size</a> or <a href=\"https://www.politico.com/news/2021/09/25/democrats-bill-joe-manchin-514152\">timeline</a> of that $3.5 trillion reconciliation package. </p><p>Now, Pelosi is pushing for a vote on just BIF, <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/pelosi-gamble-biden-infrastructure-bill-progressives-bernie-sanders-reconciliation-2021-9\">a risky gamble</a> to get one part of the agenda across the finish line. As promised, House progressives like Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/aoc-threatens-to-vote-against-moderates-infrastructure-deal-2021-9\">have said</a> they&#39;ll vote against the bipartisan bill, with prominent Senate progressive Bernie Sanders <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/bernie-sanders-infrastructure-house-progressives-tank-bill-nancy-pelosi-2021-9\">backing</a> them. </p><p>However, there is a chance both the moderate and progressive wings were bluffing after the deal fell apart, and both will <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/fight-over-infrastructure-bills-is-a-prisoners-dilemma-2021-9\">escape the prisoner&#39;s dilemma of Game Theory</a> to arrive at a compromise.</p><h2>3. Most of the public blames Republicans for the debt ceiling brinksmanship - just like before</h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6155f19d7b09e80018e593c2?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Kevin McCarthy down\" height=\"671\" width=\"1342\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>House Minority Leader Kevin McCarthy (R-CA).\n<p class=\"copyright\">Chip Somodevilla/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Over the past 25 years, standoffs like this one have become increasingly routine in Congress.</p><p>When it comes to the threat of a government shutdown - particularly the nation&#39;s longest, under former President Donald Trump, and both shutdowns during the Clinton administration in the mid-1990s - <a href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2021/09/22/republicans-usually-lose-shutdown-fights-so-why-are-they-going-there-again/\">most Americans blame the GOP</a>, without fail.</p><p>Yet despite Republicans always being blamed more for shutdowns and bringing the nation closer to defaulting on its debts, they keep doing it. </p><p>A Washington Post/ABC poll following the Clinton-era shutdowns, the first of which lasted five days and the second clocked in at 21, found 50% of Americans blaming Republicans to just 27% blaming Clinton. The clashes ultimately ended former House Speaker Newt Gingrich&#39;s reign in Congress, and emboldened Clinton going into his second term.</p><p>Whether a similar dynamic plays out with Biden depends on how bad things get and how much more polarized the public is now compared to the &#39;90s, but the polling history is not on the GOP&#39;s side.</p><h2>4. Both a shutdown and default are avoided, but Biden&#39;s infrastructure bill continues to suffer.</h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6155f0777b09e80018e59364?format=jpeg\" alt=\"US President Joe Biden convenes a virtual Covid-19 Summit on the sidelines of the UN General Assembly, on September 22, 2021, in the South Court Auditorium of the White House in Washington, DC.\" height=\"1249\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>President Joe Biden.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Brendan Smialowski/AFP via Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>With Biden&#39;s infrastructure plan <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/bernie-sanders-infrastructure-house-progressives-tank-bill-nancy-pelosi-2021-9\">already on the ropes</a> as intra-Democratic divisions have boiled over regarding how the bill was split in two, a protracted fight over the debt ceiling does nothing to help move the roughly $3.5 trillion package along.</p><p>Similar to the way narrowly avoiding a default would still have negative impacts on the economy, a languishing infrastructure bill would factor into how Wall Street analysts assess the state of the economy and which sectors are worth investing in.</p><p>With the midterms just over a year away, Biden and Democrats would like to campaign on the infrastructure bill as a major legislative accomplishment beyond the administration&#39;s pandemic response and the March stimulus bill known as the American Rescue Plan.</p><h2>5. All of this bogs down Biden&#39;s agenda through the fall, and Democrats get blamed by voters who associate government spending directly with inflation.</h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6155f235b414c100186320fe?format=jpeg\" alt=\"joe biden\" height=\"1000\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>President Joe Biden.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Pete Marovich-Pool/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>The notion of &#34;<a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/us-economy-rebound-goods-commodities-services-more-expensive-inflation-stimulus-2021-2\">overheating the economy</a>&#34; has already become a theme in the Biden presidency, and has been explicitly mentioned by notable holdouts such as Democratic Sen. Joe Manchin of West Virginia as a reason to be wary of the infrastructure bill&#39;s $3.5 trillion price tag.</p><p>On top of the $5 trillion in stimulus spending during the pandemic between the Trump and Biden administrations, those ranging from partisan critics to apolitical observers tend to tie government spending directly with inflation. </p><p>Although it&#39;s much more complicated than that, and pandemic-related supply chain issues have led to many of the most dramatic price hikes, Democrats risk losing the messaging battle on what could become one of the key issues in the 2022 midterms. </p><p>Swing voters - or at least anyone showing up to a midterm election who isn&#39;t planning on backing their party all the way down the ticket - are far more likely to have the rising price of goods sitting top of mind than squabbles over the debt ceiling that took place over a year ago.</p><p>Former President Jimmy Carter faced a similar issue, and despite <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/biden-approval-rating-new-low-midterms-timing-afghanistan-infrastructure-2021-9\">breaking with the historical trend of an incumbent president&#39;s party losing seats in Congress in the first election since taking office</a>, Carter ended up failing in his reelection bid as Ronald Reagan ran on reigning in government spending and tamping down on inflation.</p><p>While this outcome is less empirical and more closely related to campaign messaging, it may be the one with the longest staying power.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/5-ways-the-debt-ceiling-battle-in-congress-could-end-2021-9'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=WZbgswI25zU:wdS3EziQ2OM:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=WZbgswI25zU:wdS3EziQ2OM:V_sGLiPBpWU\"><img src=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=WZbgswI25zU:wdS3EziQ2OM:V_sGLiPBpWU\" border=\"0\"></img></a> <a The measure does nothing to break a deadlock initiated by Republicans that&#39;s pushing the US closer to default.</li><li><strong>Blue Origin employees speak out.</strong> <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/blue-origin-employee-accuse-company-sacrificing-safety-2021-9\">21 current and former Blue Origin staff have accused founder Jeff Bezos of sacrificing safety in an effort to win the billionaire space race</a> - and creating a toxic, sexist work culture along the way. Among the allegations is a claim that one former Blue Origin executive called women condescending terms such as &#34;baby girl&#34; and asked about their dating lives.</li><li><strong>Anti-vaxxers defy YouTube&#39;s ban.</strong> <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/non-us-anti-vaxxers-are-still-on-youtube-despite-ban-2021-9\">Anti-vaccination influencers outside the US with hundreds of thousands of subscribers appear to have evaded YouTube&#39;s new worldwide ban on vaccine misinformation. </a>They include Clemens Arvay, a German biologist whom German fact-checking site Correctiv has reported spread misinformation about mRNA vaccines.</li><li><strong>Former Nazi secretary caught.</strong> A 96-year-old former Nazi secretary, who faces 11,000 counts of accessory to murder, <a href=\"https://www.insider.com/former-nazi-concentration-camp-secretary-due-on-trial-missing-report-2021-9\">has been caught after escaping her care home on the day of her trial</a>. Irmgard Furchner previously claimed she was not aware of the killings that occurred at a concentration camp in Poland, The Associated Press reported.</li><li><strong>Wild boars attack Shakira.</strong> <a href=\"https://www.insider.com/shakira-attacked-by-wild-boars-in-barcelona-park-2021-9\">Shakira said that she was attacked by wild boars while walking in a Barcelona park with her son.</a> The Colombian singer, best known for her hits &#34;Hips Don&#39;t Lie&#34; and &#34;Waka Waka,&#34; shared the details of the incident in a series of Instagram story videos that showed her damaged, muddy handbag.</li></ul><p><strong>That&#39;s all for now. 10:08:05","updatedTime":"2021-10-01 10:08:05","title":"United says 273 employees reported they were vaccinated after the company said they would be fired over the company's strict vaccine mandate","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/uniteds-number-of-unvaccinated-employees-drops-from-593-to-320-2021-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/615601237b09e80018e599cb?format=jpeg\" alt=\"United employee with vaccination\" height=\"768\" width=\"1024\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>A United employee with a vaccination card.\n<p class=\"copyright\">United Airlines</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>United&#39;s number of unvaccinated workers dropped from 593 to 320 after they faced termination.</li>\n<li>The carrier required all nonexempt US employees to be fully inoculated by September 27 or be fired.</li>\n<li>Over 99% of the company&#39;s nonexempt US workforce has been vaccinated against COVID-19.</li>\n<li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider&#39;s business page</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Nearly half of United Airlines&#39; unvaccinated workers have now provided proof of inoculation since facing termination, the carrier said Thursday.</p><p>United has the strictest employee vaccination policy of any airline in the US. On Wednesday, United announced over 99% of its 67,000-strong US workforce <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/most-united-employees-vaccinated-against-covid-19-2021-9\">was vaccinated against COVID-19</a>, minus the 3%, or roughly 2,000 employees, who <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/united-employees-with-vaccination-exemption-put-on-personal-leave-2021-9\">applied for religious or medical exemptions</a> and are still going to work. The airline&#39;s policy, established on August 6, said all nonexempt workers were required to be vaccinated by September 27 or be fired.</p><p><a href=\"https://www.insider.com/united-airlines-said-will-fire-600-employees-defying-vaccine-mandate-2021-9\">All but 593 employees were inoculated by the deadline</a>, and United said it would begin the separation process on Thursday for unvaccinated nonexempt workers. But since Wednesday&#39;s announcement, the number of employees without proof of inoculation dropped to 320, declining by nearly half.</p><p>According to United, the reduction is driven mainly by employees uploading their vaccination cards late, and management expects the number to decrease more after individual meetings with employees find they are actually vaccinated.</p><p>&#34;Our vaccine policy continues to prove requirements work - in less than 48 hours, the number of unvaccinated employees who began the process of being separated from the company has been cut almost in half, dropping from 593 to 320. That means 99.5 percent of United&#39;s U.S. employees have now chosen to get vaccinated, excluding those who sought an exemption,&#34; United said in a statement.</p><p>Other US airlines have yet to mandate vaccinations for employees, though some are trying to incentivize the shot through reward or punishment. Delta Air Lines announced in August that unvaccinated employees would be <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/delta-workers-need-vaccine-or-pay-200-extra-for-healthcare-2021-8\">forced to pay an extra $200</a> for the company health-insurance plan, while Southwest is offering 16 hours of extra pay for inoculated workers. Southwest CEO Gary Kelly said he did not believe in the company mandating vaccinations but added that the <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/biden-vaccine-mandate-businesses-employers-osha-good-should-go-further-2021-9\">federal government may implement requirements</a>.</p><p>&#34;So we at Southwest Airlines may be compelled by federal law to require employees to be vaccinated, and we will be prepared for that,&#34; Kelly told staff, according to CNBC.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the 10:08:05","updatedTime":"2021-10-01 10:08:05","title":"Blue Origin employees say they wouldn't feel safe riding the company's rockets, and it's 'lucky' nothing has happened","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/blue-origin-employees-letter-new-shepard-rockets-not-safe-2021-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/60f21f457b0ec5001800a9f5?format=jpeg\" alt=\"jeff bezos hands together praying gesture composite image with rocket launching\" height=\"1500\" width=\"2000\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Jeff Bezos (left) launched aboard Blue Origin&#39;s New Shepard rocket (right) in July.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Anushree Fadnavis/Reuters; Blue Origin</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/blue-origin-employee-accuse-company-sacrificing-safety-2021-9\">Twenty-one Blue Origin employees</a> published a whistle-blowing <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/blue-origin-employee-accuse-company-sacrificing-safety-2021-9\">open letter</a> on Thursday.</li>\n<li>Some employees said they wouldn&#39;t ride a <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/amazon-elon-musk-spacex-just-as-litigious-as-jeff-bezos-2021-9\">Blue Origin</a> rocket due to <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/jeff-bezos-risk-blue-origin-rocket-2021-6\">safety</a> concerns. One said it&#39;s &#34;lucky&#34; nothing has happened.</li>\n<li>No federal agency regulates passenger <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/how-bezos-space-trip-compares-truck-driving-warehouse-work-2021-7\">safety</a> on <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/blue-origin-announces-2-passengers-next-spaceflight-october-12-2021-9\">private spaceflights</a>. </li>\n<li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider&#39;s business page</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>In a <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/blue-origin-employee-accuse-company-sacrificing-safety-2021-9\">scalding open letter</a>, a group of current and former Blue Origin employees said they would not fly aboard the company&#39;s rocket because they don&#39;t think it&#39;s <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/blue-origin-rocket-emergency-escape-system-jeff-bezos-2021-7\">safe</a> enough.</p><p>Jeff Bezos, who founded the company in 2000, launched to the edge of space aboard its New Shepard rocket in July. Since that flight, Blue Origin has opened ticket sales, and four customers are scheduled to launch on October 12. But <a href=\"https://www.lioness.co/post/bezos-wants-to-create-a-better-future-in-space-his-company-blue-origin-is-stuck-in-a-toxic-past\">the new letter</a> says that Blue Origin&#39;s leadership has ignored employees&#39; safety concerns in favor of &#34;making progress for Jeff&#34; and accelerating New Shepard&#39;s launch schedule.</p><p>The only named author on the letter is Alexandra Abrams, who used to head Blue Origin&#39;s employee communications. She published the essay on the website Lioness on Thursday, but says that 20 other current and former Blue Origin employees co-wrote it. None of those co-authors were named, but <a href=\"https://www.cbsnews.com/news/blue-origin-alexandra-abrams-safety-workplace-culture/?ftag=CNM-00-10aab7e&linkId=1339498959895\">CBS News</a> has spoken with five of them. The letter also made claims of a culture of sexism, harassment, and intolerance to dissent at Blue Origin.</p><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/614c6b24c2c9630018f5ef77?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Blue Origin founder Jeff Bezos wears a pair of reflective aviation glasses under a cowboy hat\" height=\"1619\" width=\"2158\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Blue Origin founder Jeff Bezos with aviation glasses that belonged to Amelia Earhart.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Joe Raedle/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>New Shepard has flown successfully 15 times without people on board and once with passengers, when Bezos went. The rocket has an emergency system that can jettison the passenger capsule away from a failing rocket if necessary.</p><p>However, the letter said: &#34;In the opinion of an engineer who has signed on to this essay, &#39;Blue Origin has been lucky that nothing has happened so far.&#39; Many of this essay&#39;s authors say they would not fly on a Blue Origin vehicle.&#34;</p><p>Two former Blue Origin employees confirmed to <a href=\"https://www.cbsnews.com/news/blue-origin-alexandra-abrams-safety-workplace-culture/?ftag=CNM-00-10aab7e&linkId=1339498959895\">CBS News</a> that they would not feel comfortable riding a Blue Origin spacecraft.</p><p>In a statement emailed to Insider, Blue Origin said that Abrams &#34;was dismissed for cause two years ago after repeated warnings for issues involving federal export control regulations.&#34; Abrams has denied that she received any such warnings.</p><p>At least 17 top engineers and leaders have left Blue Origin this summer, many of them in the week after Bezos&#39;s spaceflight, <a href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2021/08/20/jeff-bezos-blue-origin-losing-top-talent-during-nasa-lander-fight.html\">CNBC</a> reported in August. The reasons for their departures aren&#39;t clear, though <a href=\"https://www.glassdoor.com/Overview/Working-at-Blue-Origin-EI_IE782684.11,22.htm\">Glassdoor</a> ratings suggest that just 19% of Blue Origin employees approve of its CEO, Bob Smith. That&#39;s compared to a 92% approval rating for SpaceX&#39;s Elon Musk and 77% for United Launch Alliance&#39;s Tory Bruno.</p><p>Blue Origin&#39;s statement also said: &#34;We stand by our safety record and believe that New Shepard is the safest space vehicle ever designed or built.&#34;</p><p>But the open letter said that safety was &#34;the driving force&#34; behind the decision to publish it for many of its co-authors. It also said that in 2018, when someone new took over one particular team, the manager discovered that the team had documented &#34;more than 1,000 problem reports&#34; related to the company&#39;s rocket engines. None of those reports had been addressed, the letter said.</p><p>What&#39;s more, the letter added that Blue Origin has frequently denied requests &#34;for additional engineers, staff, or spending,&#34; while adding more responsibilities to teams that are too small to handle them.</p><p>&#34;Employees are often told to &#39;be careful with Jeff&#39;s money,&#39; to &#39;not ask for more,&#39; and to &#39;be grateful,&#39;&#34; the letter said.</p><h2>Commercial rocket passengers fly at their own risk</h2><figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/60c10b58b50ed500185e3e69?format=jpeg\" alt=\"The New Shepard crew capsule parachutes to a landing at Blue Origin&#39;s Launch Site One in Texas on January 14.\" height=\"2159\" width=\"2879\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>The New Shepard crew capsule parachutes to a landing at Blue Origin&#39;s Launch Site One in Texas, January 14, 2021.\n<p class=\"copyright\">Blue Origin</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><p>Spaceflight is always risky. About 1% of US human spaceflights have resulted in a fatal accident, according to an <a href=\"https://aerospace.org/sites/default/files/2020-11/Koller-Nield_HumanSpaceflight_20201112.pdf\" data-analytics-module=\"body_link\" data-analytics-post-depth=\"20\" data-uri=\"3976cee0dc682fdb12b0901fcea4fef1\">analysis</a> published earlier this year.</p><p>&#34;That&#39;s pretty high. It&#39;s about 10,000 times more dangerous than flying on a commercial airliner,&#34; George Nield, a co-author of that report, previously told Insider. Nield formerly served as the Federal Aviation Administration&#39;s associate administrator and led its Office of Commercial Space Transportation.</p><p>&#34;In order to learn how to do this safer, more reliably, and more cost effectively, many people believe we need to keep gaining experience by having more and more of these flights,&#34; he added.</p><p>Currently, no federal agency regulates the safety of passengers on private commercial spaceflights. For now, the Federal Aviation Administration&#39;s job is only to ensure that rocket launches are safe for people on the ground and don&#39;t pose a threat to other aircraft.</p><p>But in a statement emailed to Insider, the FAA said that it was &#34;reviewing&#34; the open letter.</p><p>&#34;The FAA takes every safety allegation seriously, and the agency is reviewing the information,&#34; the statement said.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/blue-origin-employees-letter-new-shepard-rockets-not-safe-2021-9'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=OvopfLhXOVs:OjH_gzZMi7I:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img 10:08:05","updatedTime":"2021-10-01 10:08:05","title":"#CitadelScandal is trending on Twitter as retail traders express fresh outrage over allegations around meme-stock trading","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/citadel-scandal-hashtag-twitter-retail-traders-meme-stocks-gamestop-2021-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6155e295b414c10018631aad?format=jpeg\" alt=\"robinhood reddit citadel hearing\" height=\"400\" width=\"800\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>Getty Images / Chris Delmas\n<p class=\"copyright\">Getty Images / Chris Delmas</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>#CitadelScandal was a top trending hashtag on Twitter as retail traders expressed renewed outrage over Robinhood&#39;s trading restrictions in January.</li>\n<li>A new lawsuit filed alleges Citadel Securities and Robinhood were in contact ahead of the trading halt. </li>\n<li>Citadel Securities has said it did not pressure Robinhood to restrict trading. </li>\n<li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider&#39;s business page</a>.</li>\n</ul><p><a href=\"https://twitter.com/search?q=%23CitadelScandal&src=trend_click&pt=1442921058785316865&vertical=trendstical=trends\">#CitadelScandal</a> was the number two trending hashtag on Twitter Thursday amid renewed outrage from retail traders over allegations regarding the January 28 meme-stock trading halt.</p><p>The hashtags #ApesNotLeaving and #VladTenevLied were also trending, continuing a Twitter fight between retail traders and Citadel Securities following a class-action lawsuit that was filed in federal court in Miami on September 22. </p><p>In response to the trending hashtags, Citadel Securities <a href=\"https://twitter.com/citsecurities/status/1443660583862161417\">tweeted</a> it &#34;FIRST learned of Robinhood&#39;s trading restrictions from posts on Twitter - as evidenced by real-time communications.&#34;</p><p>The class-action lawsuit alleges that market maker Citadel Securities conspired with Robinhood to drive down the price of meme stocks such as GameStop and AMC on January 28 when buying was halted on the trading app.</p><p>&#34;On January 27, 2021, the day before the restrictions were implemented, high level employees of Citadel Securities and Robinhood had numerous communications with each other that indicate that Citadel applied pressure on Robinhood,&#34; the lawsuit states.</p><p>In response, retail traders on Twitter began tweeting about the Citadel Securities founder, promoting the hashtag #KenGriffinLied on Tuesday.</p><p><a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/citadel-ken-griffin-robinhood-gamestop-meme-stocks-conspiracy-theorists-2021-9\">Citadel Securities fired back</a> in a series of tweets, saying it &#34;never requested, intimated, agreed or otherwise sought to limit or to restrict the trading&#34; of meme stocks.</p><p>&#34;It must frustrate the conspiracy theorists to no end that Vlad and I have never texted, called or met each other,&#34; he said in an emailed statement to Insider.</p><p>Robinhood&#39;s decision to halt buying of meme stocks such as GameStop prompted a <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/congress-gamestop-stock-hearing-robinhood-reddit-citadel-what-happened-2021-2?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingestgest\">congressional hearing</a> and several lawsuits. During the hearing, lawmakers asked Griffin if anyone in his organization pressured Robinhood to restrict trading, to which he responded, &#34;absolutely not.&#34;</p><p>In a previous statement to Insider, Robinhood said Citadel Securities and other market makers didn&#39;t pressure the trading app to restrict trading. </p><p>&#34;These complaints attempt to create a false narrative of collusion,&#34; the company said. </p><p>Robinhood&#39;s business model relies on payment for order flow, wherein users&#39; trades are routed to market makers such as Citadel Securities, which then execute the transaction and collect on the difference between the bid and ask price. The practice has come under increased scrutiny since the meme-stock saga, and the Securities and Exchange Commission is considering tighter regulation. </p><p>Robinhood&#39;s CEO <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/robinhood-vlad-tenev-critics-target-retail-traders-gamestop-2021-9?utm_source=markets&utm_medium=ingestgest\">hit back</a> at critics of the app and of commission-free trading this week in an op-ed for the Wall Street Journal. </p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a 2021 20:05:34 +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/6155e2b67b09e80018e58e90?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"85c082701c058c24ed78f26b3d4b6568","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn55@2020_6/2021/10/01/02-08-30-396_1d3d6a4ed16a825a.webp","destWidth":678,"destHeight":508,"sourceBytes":16866,"destBytes":16866,"author":"ndailey@insider.com (Natasha Dailey)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/6155e295b414c10018631aad?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn15@2020_4/2021/10/01/02-08-32-758_3b65965f2ed8318b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn83@2020_1/2021/10/01/02-08-34-915_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=CTeBCqks-E8:mHquP9Cfeg4:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn71@2020_3/2021/10/01/02-08-35-601_ab9d76fa27956e50.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=CTeBCqks-E8:mHquP9Cfeg4:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn27@2020_5/2021/10/01/02-08-31-892_55888931e604e8cc.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn99@2020_6/2021/10/01/02-08-33-043_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=CTeBCqks-E8:mHquP9Cfeg4:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn32@2020_3/2021/10/01/02-08-34-358_e4935ad9dccd9a30.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/CTeBCqks-E8":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn59@2020_6/2021/10/01/02-08-35-121_8d26dae41e0495af.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1633054085744},{"createdTime":"2021-10-01 10:08:05","updatedTime":"2021-10-01 10:08:05","title":"A man developed 'restless anal syndrome' weeks after recovering from a mild case of COVID-19","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/restless-anal-syndrome-man-developed-symptoms-after-covid-19-recovery-2021-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/5e8fb0ee92e8ba086f4a7715?format=jpeg\" alt=\"medical coronavirus flu virus covid19 hospital doctor nurse tools stethoscope blood pressure pills vitamins medicine pharmacy pharmaceutical lab vaccine cox 28\" height=\"1667\" width=\"2500\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Crystal Cox/Business Insider</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li aria-level=\"1\">A 77-year-old man developed a pain deep in his anus weeks after having COVID-19.</li>\n<li aria-level=\"1\">He had never experienced the restless discomfort before, and it didn&#39;t improve after bowel movements.</li>\n<li aria-level=\"1\">Doctors told him it was an anal variant of restless leg syndrome, which has been linked to COVID-19.</li>\n<li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider&#39;s business page</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>A man in Japan developed &#34;deep anal discomfort&#34; several weeks after he recovered from COVID-19, according to a recent case report published in <a href=\"https://bmcinfectdis.biomedcentral.com/articles/10.1186/s12879-021-06683-7\">BMC Infectious Diseases</a>.</p><p>Doctors at Tokyo University Hospital diagnosed him with &#34;restless anal syndrome,&#34; an unusual variant of restless leg syndrome. RLS variants have been observed in the <a href=\"https://bmcneurol.biomedcentral.com/articles/10.1186/s12883-020-01875-1\">abdomen</a>, <a href=\"https://www.jstage.jst.go.jp/article/internalmedicine/55/18/55_55.6815/_article\">bladder</a>, and <a href=\"https://www.jns-journal.com/article/S0022-510X(12)00341-3/fulltext\">mouth</a>, but this is the <a href=\"https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/?term=restless+anal+syndrome\">first anal presentation</a> described in medical literature.</p><p>The 77-year-old man reported a restless discomfort approximately 10 cm - the length of a golf pencil - <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/microbiology-professor-china-anal-swab-test-covid-19-makes-sense-2021-1\">deep in his anus</a>. He told doctors he had the urge to move his bowels, but pooping didn&#39;t alleviate the feeling.</p><p>His symptoms worsened in the evening and in periods of rest, which is consistent with restless leg syndrome, the doctors noted. Additionally, he was able to get some relief with exercise - another common feature of RLS.</p><p>A colonoscopy revealed that, aside from a few hemorrhoids, nothing was wrong inside the man&#39;s rectum. He had no brain abnormalities, bladder disturbance, or <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/covid-19-may-cause-erectile-dysfunction-small-study-finds-2021-8\">erectile dysfunction</a>. In addition a bit of <a href=\"https://www.insider.com/one-in-five-covid-19-patients-develop-mental-health-disorders-2020-11\">anxiety and insomnia</a>, the restless feeling was his only health issue since COVID-19.</p><p>Several weeks earlier, the man had been admitted to the hospital with a relatively mild case of COVID-19 that included sore throat, cough, and fever. He had a low-grade fever for 10 days and was treated for mild pneumonia.</p><p>The anal discomfort started after he recovered from his respiratory symptoms, sending him back to the hospital. The doctors determined that because the patient had never experienced the restlessness in his anus before, it was likely a <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/covid-19-long-haulers-brain-fog-neurological-disorders-2021-5\">COVID-related syndrome</a>.</p><p>After a course of Clonazepam, a drug used to treat seizures, the discomfort in his anus resolved.</p><p>Long-haulers have reported some strange lingering symptoms, including regular RLS and other neurological disorders. Symptoms like <a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/15-year-old-shares-long-covid-symptoms-brain-fog-fatigue-2021-8\">brain fog</a> and ringing ears can last for months after the initial infection, putting <a href=\"https://www.insider.com/long-term-covid-sufferers-are-killing-themselves-heres-why-2021-4\">COVID survivors at elevated risk of </a>psychological distress.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/restless-anal-syndrome-man-developed-symptoms-after-covid-19-recovery-2021-9'>Business Insider</a></div><div class=\"feedflare\">\n<a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=EMKu13_p8AE:bjxR9MdK9d4:yIl2AUoC8zA\"><img border=\"0\"></img></a> <a href=\"http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?a=EMKu13_p8AE:bjxR9MdK9d4:gIN9vFwOqvQ\"><img +0000","feedId":22,"bgimg":"https://i.insider.com/61561a7a7b09e80018e5a47b?format=jpeg","linkMd5":"5064d110673f856be55cb20bfa9385f9","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn10@2020_5/2021/10/01/02-08-30-985_8093de4736afb54a.webp","destWidth":2222,"destHeight":1666,"sourceBytes":143396,"destBytes":143396,"author":"amichelson@insider.com (Andrea Michelson)","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://i.insider.com/5e8fb0ee92e8ba086f4a7715?format=jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn59@2020_4/2021/10/01/02-08-32-633_a0c17cd8751aef3e.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=yIl2AUoC8zA":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn83@2020_1/2021/10/01/02-08-34-915_cc3ef43fc8ff5801.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=EMKu13_p8AE:bjxR9MdK9d4:F7zBnMyn0Lo":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn100@2020_6/2021/10/01/02-08-36-470_53aa31996a680aad.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=EMKu13_p8AE:bjxR9MdK9d4:V_sGLiPBpWU":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn95@2020_3/2021/10/01/02-08-31-526_e331e7bcc6bda179.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?d=qj6IDK7rITs":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn99@2020_6/2021/10/01/02-08-33-043_740defb435ea442b.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~ff/businessinsider?i=EMKu13_p8AE:bjxR9MdK9d4:gIN9vFwOqvQ":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn12@2020_2/2021/10/01/02-08-34-784_485e2bd8ca99fbe3.webp","http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/businessinsider/~4/EMKu13_p8AE":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn44@2020_6/2021/10/01/02-08-32-247_cb526e192b3e1679.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1633054085590},{"createdTime":"2021-10-01 10:08:05","updatedTime":"2021-10-01 10:08:05","title":"Chinese assets will shrink from big investors' portfolios amid regulatory concerns, new data shows","link":"https://www.businessinsider.com/chinese-assets-will-shrink-from-portfolios-amid-regulatory-concerns-2021-9","description":"<figure>\n\t<img src=\"https://i.insider.com/6102caefea74d40019b9a56e?format=jpeg\" alt=\"Chinese stocks China crackdown markets\" height=\"2567\" width=\"5134\" charset=\"\">\n<figcaption>\n<p class=\"copyright\">Jie Zhao/Getty Images</p>\n</figcaption>\n</figure><ul class=\"summary-list\">\n<li>Big investors are going to reduce their exposure to Chinese assets, new data show. </li>\n<li>About 12% are planning to cut back on their China exposure, which is three times as many as in 2019. </li>\n<li>The reduction comes as China is cracking down on the tech sector and cryptocurrencies. </li>\n<li id=\"recirc\"><a href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/?hprecirc-bullet\">See more stories on Insider&#39;s business page</a>.</li>\n</ul><p>Big investors are planning to cut back on their exposure to China amid regulatory fears, new Invesco data show. </p><p>Over the summer, Invesco polled more than 200 professional investors, such as pension funds and insurers, and discovered that 12% of them planned to reduce Chinese assets in their portfolios. That&#39;s triple the number from <a href=\"https://www.invesco.com/content/dam/invesco/invest-china/en/pdf/expert-study/Invesco-The-China-position_Nov2019.pdf\">Invesco&#39;s last such survey in 2019</a>.</p><p>On top of that, 64% of big investors now plan to up their China exposure, compared to 80% in 2019. <a href=\"https://www.ft.com/content/090f3430-6b25-49cb-a38c-2870dd038a16\">The Financial Times first reported</a> the contrast.</p><p>China has been <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/china-tech-regulation-crackdown-tougher-legislation-key-industries-2021-8\">cracking down on the tech sector</a> and cryptocurrencies this year, and has signaled it will create new laws for other key industries as well. Between the regulatory crackdown and the Evergrande crisis, investors have been weighing whether the country is a safe bet, renowned economist <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/evergrande-debt-crisis-china-crackdown-markets-mohamed-el-erian-investing-2021-9\">Mohamed El-Erian said on CNBC</a> earlier this week.</p><p>Prominent investors have been vocal about cutting back on Chinese assets. Ark Invest&#39;s Cathie Wood said the firm has <a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/cathie-wood-ark-china-investments-crackdown-jdlogistics-pinduoduo-2021-9\">&#34;dramatically&#34; offloaded Chinese stocks</a> because of Beijing&#39;s crackdown on big business. And legendary investor George Soros called BlackRock&#39;s push into China a &#34;<a href=\"https://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/george-soros-blackrock-china-mistake-investing-chinese-stocks-markets-2021-9\">tragic mistake</a>.&#34;</p><p>Meanwhile, Invesco has been ramping up its presence in China&#39;s mutual fund industry and now has $83 billion in assets under management, up from $19 billion in 2016, the FT reported. </p><p>Despite the latest survey results, the $1.61 trillion fund manager remains upbeat about China.</p><p>&#34;China is continuing to open up and become friendlier to global investors; access has become more convenient; and the attractiveness of the [domestic] assets has increased in the last few years as a result of the government&#39;s effort to grow the economy and its capital markets,&#34; Andrew Lo, Invesco&#39;s head of Asia Pacific, told the FT.</p><div class=\"read-original\">Read the original article on <a href='https://www.businessinsider.com/chinese-assets-will-shrink-from-portfolios-amid-regulatory-concerns-2021-9'>Business
